data.summary: SQLite3 from 3.6.0 to and including 3.27.2 is vulnerable to heap out-of-bound read in the rtreenode() function when handling invalid rtree tables.

more_details.description: SQLite3 from 3.6.0 to and including 3.27.2 is vulnerable to heap out-of-bound read in the rtreenode() function when handling invalid rtree tables.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: SQLite3 is vulnerable to heap out-of-bound read in the rtreenode() function when handling invalid rtree tables.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[SQLite](https://www.sqlite.org/index.html) is a very popular lightweight SQL database engine. An [R-Tree](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/R-tree) is a special index that is designed for doing range queries. R-Trees are most commonly used in geospatial systems where each entry is a rectangle with minimum and maximum X and Y coordinates. Given a query rectangle, an R-Tree is able to quickly find all entries that are contained within the query rectangle or which overlap the query rectangle.

Even though no exploit is published, it's possible in theory to cause a heap out-of-bound read using a crafted rtree table, leading to potential disclosure of information.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Non-default (and rare) configuration

data.summary: A cleartext transmission of sensitive information vulnerability exists in curl <v7.88.0 that could cause HSTS functionality fail when multiple URLs are requested serially. Using its HSTS support, curl can be instructed to use HTTPS instead of usingan insecure clear-text HTTP step even when HTTP is provided in the URL. ThisHSTS mechanism would however surprisingly be ignored by subsequent transferswhen done on the same command line because the state would not be properlycarried on.

more_details.description: A cleartext transmission of sensitive information vulnerability exists in curl <v7.88.0 that could cause HSTS functionality fail when multiple URLs are requested serially. Using its HSTS support, curl can be instructed to use HTTPS instead of usingan insecure clear-text HTTP step even when HTTP is provided in the URL. ThisHSTS mechanism would however surprisingly be ignored by subsequent transferswhen done on the same command line because the state would not be properlycarried on.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: A design problem in curl may lead to HSTS bypass when using HSTS caching in-memory.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Curl](https://curl.se/) is a command-line tool for transferring data from or to a server, using various protocols like HTTP, FTP, SMTP, and more.
[HTTP Strict Transport Security](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Security/HTTP_strict_transport_security) (HSTS) is a simple and widely supported standard to protect visitors by ensuring that their browsers always connect to a website over HTTPS. HSTS exists to remove the need for the common, insecure practice of redirecting users from `http://` to `https://` URLs.

Curl supports `HSTS` local cache which can be used through the command line using the following syntax: `curl --hsts hsts.txt https://hsts.example.com`.
Curl also supports caching these `HSTS` headers in-memory instead of a file, by using the following syntax: `curl --hsts "" https://hsts.example.com`

It was discovered that when using the in-memory HSTS caching (`--hsts ""`) of curl, if more than one URL of the same domain is passed to the curl command line, and at least one of them (except the first one) starts with `http://` instead of `https://`, the request sent by curl will bypass the `HSTS` filter and use the insecure clear-text HTTP protocol.
This is despite the fact that the `--hsts` option should force the use of HTTPS.

For example, the following command line is insecure (take note of the use of in-memory HSTS caching and the same domain URLs): `curl --hsts "" https://hsts.example.com http://hsts.example.com`

Note: only the curl command line using the `--hsts` option is vulnerable. `libcurl` is not affected by this vulnerability.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has a detailed technical explanation published, that can aid in exploit development
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: HackerOne report has a detailed technical writeup that leads to HSTS bypass.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The CVSS does not reflect the contextual prerequisites required to exploit the vulnerability.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
1. The vulnerability is exploitable only when `curl` is executed using the CLI with the `--hsts` option with an empty argument that caches the HSTS hosts in memory, and then subsequent HTTP requests to the same domain in the same command. (e.g. `curl --hsts "" https://hsts.example.com`)
2. The exploitation of this vulnerability may only be useful in environments exposed to Man in the Middle attacks. This would give the attacker the ability to perform Man in the Middle on non-encrypted clear text communication, which is easier compared to encrypted communication when HTTPS is used.
3. The vulnerable application or server should execute `curl` that would make multiple requests to the same domain in a single Curl command, which is not common. Alternatively, the attacker should be able to control the requested URL that `curl` access and set it.

data.summary: Python UU Encoding Methods Filename Newline Character Handling Buffer Overflow

more_details.description: Python contains an overflow condition in UU Encoding Methods. The issue is triggered as newline characters are not properly validated when passed to filenames. This may allow a context-dependent attacker to cause a buffer overflow, resulting in a denial of service in a process built with the language or potentially allowing the execution of arbitrary code.

data.summary: Improper input validation of octal strings in Python stdlib ipaddress 3.10 and below allows unauthenticated remote attackers to perform indeterminate SSRF, RFI, and LFI attacks on many programs that rely on Python stdlib ipaddress. IP address octects are left stripped instead of evaluated as valid IP addresses.

more_details.description: Improper input validation of octal strings in Python stdlib ipaddress 3.10 and below allows unauthenticated remote attackers to perform indeterminate SSRF, RFI, and LFI attacks on many programs that rely on Python stdlib ipaddress. IP address octects are left stripped instead of evaluated as valid IP addresses.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Incorrect IP parsing in Python ipaddress module can lead to IP address confusion.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
In Python's built-in `ipaddress` module, when parsing IPv4 strings, leading zeros are incorrectly ignored and are not assumed to specify octal (base 8) octets. IP addresses are left stripped instead of evaluated as valid octal IP addresses. This behavior is problematic since many other tools (such as Bash) can properly handle octal IP addresses.

An attacker can exploit this vulnerability if Python is used with the  `ipaddress.ip_address` or `ipaddress.ip_network` functions for parsing an IP address received as a string from user input.

The impact from this vulnerability is an IP address confusion between two different components:

1. Python’s `ipaddress` module which will misinterpret an octal IP address 
2. Some other IP address parser that correctly handles octal IP addresses, such as Bash. 

For example, in the following PoC the 1st `ping` invocation will access ip address "8.8.8.8" but the 2nd invocation will (incorrectly) access "10.8.8.8":

```
SUSPECT = '010.8.8.8'
BAD_IP = ipaddress.ip_address(SUSPECT)
subprocess.check_output("ping -W3 -v -c1 "+str(SUSPECT), shell=True, universal_newlines=True)
subprocess.check_output("ping -W3 -v -c1 "+str(BAD_IP), shell=True, universal_newlines=True)
```

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
The impact of exploiting the issue depends on the context of surrounding software. A severe impact such as RCE is not guaranteed.

data.summary: Python Lib/webbrowser.py WindowsDefault.open() Function URL Handling Arbitrary Command Execution

more_details.description: Python contains a flaw in the WindowsDefault.open() function in Lib/webbrowser.py that is triggered as input via URLs is not properly validated before invoking os.startfile(). This may allow a context-dependent attacker to execute arbitrary commands.

data.summary: MiniZip in zlib through 1.3 has an integer overflow and resultant heap-based buffer overflow in zipOpenNewFileInZip4_64 via a long filename, comment, or extra field. NOTE: MiniZip is not a supported part of the zlib product.

more_details.description: MiniZip in zlib through 1.3 has an integer overflow and resultant heap-based buffer overflow in zipOpenNewFileInZip4_64 via a long filename, comment, or extra field. NOTE: MiniZip is not a supported part of the zlib product.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: A heap buffer overflow in zlib may lead to remote code execution when parsing a malicious archive.
high_profile_info.Resolution:
##### Development mitigations

Make sure that files with names larger than 65536 characters are not parsed using `zlib`.

Also, a fix currently exists in the `develop` branch of `zlib` and can be deployed manually.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: PoC demonstrates a heap overflow that crashes the application. Although not demonstrated, it is likely that an RCE exploit could be developed, since zip-processing may allow many heap-shaping primitives needed for a full RCE exploit.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: An attacker could compromise a server that is using the `zlib` library to zip or unzip any files.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The CVSS score does not reflect the context-dependent nature of this vulnerability.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Remote code execution.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: An attacker must find a way to upload a crafted zip archive, that is subsequently processed by the vulnerable `zipOpenNewFileInZip4_64` function.

data.summary: The PKCS#11 feature in ssh-agent in OpenSSH before 9.3p2 has an insufficiently trustworthy search path, leading to remote code execution if an agent is forwarded to an attacker-controlled system. (Code in /usr/lib is not necessarily safe for loading into ssh-agent.) NOTE: this issue exists because of an incomplete fix for CVE-2016-10009.

more_details.description: The PKCS#11 feature in ssh-agent in OpenSSH before 9.3p2 has an insufficiently trustworthy search path, leading to remote code execution if an agent is forwarded to an attacker-controlled system. (Code in /usr/lib is not necessarily safe for loading into ssh-agent.) NOTE: this issue exists because of an incomplete fix for CVE-2016-10009.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: A design problem in OpenSSH client may lead to remote code execution when using agent forwarding and connecting to a malicious SSH server.
high_profile_info.Resolution:
##### Deployment mitigations

A possible mitigation for this issue, proposed by the OpenSSH's developers, is forwarding an agent while having an empty allowlist (`ssh-agent -P ''`), or by setting up an allowlist that includes only designated provider libraries.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Remote Code Execution

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has multiple mentions in general media
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: OpenSSH is a well-known SSH server.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Qualys has published a Proof-of-Concept that demonstrates remote code execution with a technical writeup.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
A machine running OpenSSH client is only exploitable when using agent forwarding (`ssh -A`) and connecting to an attacker-controlled SSH server.
Moreover, the presence of specific libraries on the victim system is necessary for exploitation to occur.

The current exploit PoC relies on all of the following non-default packages being installed on Ubuntu 22.04: `eclipse-titan`, `libkf5sonnetui5` and `libns3-3v5`.
However - future exploits might be able to achieve RCE even in a default configuration of Ubuntu or other distros.

data.summary: vim is vulnerable to Heap-based Buffer Overflow

more_details.description: vim is vulnerable to Heap-based Buffer Overflow

data.summary: Integer Overflow or Wraparound in GitHub repository vim/vim prior to 9.0.1532.

more_details.description: Integer Overflow or Wraparound in GitHub repository vim/vim prior to 9.0.1532.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: (Non-Issue) Buffer overflow in vim leads to denial of service and potentially code execution when running crafted vim commands.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Vim](https://www.vim.org/) is a free, open-source, screen-based text editor program for Unix.
Vim has an `Ex mode` that allows entering Ex commands and is designed for Batch processing.

The Ex, or colon, commands are based on the line editor named ex. In general, they operate on the document as a whole, or large portions of it (although there are commands to perform essentially every editing task).

It was discovered that when sourcing a file using Vim `Ex mode`, a heap overflow may occur, which leads to a denial of service.

`vim` can be run with one or more flags. These flags include, but are not limited to:

* `-e`: With the `-e` flag, the user enters Ex mode. The Ex mode is similar to the command line mode as it also allows you to enter Ex commands.
* `-s`: With the `-s` flag, the user can silence the ex mode, to support batch commands.
* `-S`: With the `-S` flag, the user sources the file after loading it.

The issue requires the victim to run an attacker's specially crafted file in `Ex mode` and source it as well.
An example of a vulnerable command line:
`vim -e -s -S {malicious_file}`

Opening files with vim in this specific mode is highly unlikely.

This vulnerability has no security impact at all since if an attacker can run arbitrary vim commands, then the attacker can also execute arbitrary shell commands using the exclamation mark, and does not need this vulnerability to achieve code execution. For example running the vim command `!ls` will execute the shell command `ls`.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The CVSS does not reflect the contextual prerequisites required to exploit the vulnerability.

data.summary: An issue was discovered in Python before 3.11.1. An unnecessary quadratic algorithm exists in one path when processing some inputs to the IDNA (RFC 3490) decoder, such that a crafted, unreasonably long name being presented to the decoder could lead to a CPU denial of service. Hostnames are often supplied by remote servers that could be controlled by a malicious actor; in such a scenario, they could trigger excessive CPU consumption on the client attempting to make use of an attacker-supplied supposed hostname. For example, the attack payload could be placed in the Location header of an HTTP response with status code 302. A fix is planned in 3.11.1, 3.10.9, 3.9.16, 3.8.16, and 3.7.16.

more_details.description: An issue was discovered in Python before 3.11.1. An unnecessary quadratic algorithm exists in one path when processing some inputs to the IDNA (RFC 3490) decoder, such that a crafted, unreasonably long name being presented to the decoder could lead to a CPU denial of service. Hostnames are often supplied by remote servers that could be controlled by a malicious actor; in such a scenario, they could trigger excessive CPU consumption on the client attempting to make use of an attacker-supplied supposed hostname. For example, the attack payload could be placed in the Location header of an HTTP response with status code 302. A fix is planned in 3.11.1, 3.10.9, 3.9.16, 3.8.16, and 3.7.16.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Inefficient decoding algorithm in Python's idna module can lead to excessive CPU consumption when decoding a crafted domain name.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Python](https://www.python.org/) is a high-level, interpreted programming language known for its simplicity, readability, and versatility.
The Python standard library is a collection of modules and packages that are part of the Python distribution by default and provides a wide range of functionality for common tasks, such as working with data structures, file I/O, networking, and more.
IDNA (Internationalized Domain Names in Applications) encoding and decoding is part of Python's standard library, specifically the `encodings.idna` module, which provides functions to convert domain names between their ASCII and Unicode forms according to the IDNA specification.

When processing certain domain names as input, the `idna.decode()` function could cause excessive CPU consumption and result in a DoS. Since hostnames are often supplied by remote servers that could be controlled by an attacker, the vulnerability could be exploited by triggering the CPU consumption on a client attempting to process a crafted, unreasonably long name.

Note that according to IDNA specifications, the IDNA label names cannot be more than 63 ASCII characters. However, Python's `idna` module does not enforce this restriction.

Vulnerable code snippet #1 -
```python
import idna
idna.decode(external_input)
```

Vulnerable code snippet #2 -
```python
external_input_bytes.decode('idna')
```

Note that some Python 3rd-party libraries, such as [requests](https://pypi.org/project/requests/) may be vulnerable to this issue remotely. For example, the `urllib.request.HTTPRedirectHandler` class passes the `Location` response header to the idna module directly, when parsing an HTTP 302 redirect response.
high_profile_info.Resolution:
##### Development mitigations

As an IDNA label must not be longer than 63 characters, a simple check before the call to the `decode('idna')` function would mitigate this vulnerability -
```python
if len(idna_label) <= 63:
    decoded_name = idna_label.decode('idna')
else:
    # FAIL
```

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The attacker must find remote input that propagates to the idna.decode() API function

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Public exploit demonstrates DoS

data.summary: A vulnerability in input validation exists in curl <8.0 during communication using the TELNET protocol may allow an attacker to pass on maliciously crafted user name and "telnet options" during server negotiation. The lack of proper input scrubbing allows an attacker to send content or perform option negotiation without the application's intent. This vulnerability could be exploited if an application allows user input, thereby enabling attackers to execute arbitrary code on the system.

more_details.description: A vulnerability in input validation exists in curl <8.0 during communication using the TELNET protocol may allow an attacker to pass on maliciously crafted user name and "telnet options" during server negotiation. The lack of proper input scrubbing allows an attacker to send content or perform option negotiation without the application's intent. This vulnerability could be exploited if an application allows user input, thereby enabling attackers to execute arbitrary code on the system.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Improper command sanitization in curl can lead to content passing through specific options when telnet is enabled.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Curl](https://curl.se/) is a command-line tool for transferring data from or to a server, using various protocols like HTTP, FTP, SMTP, and more.
An issue has been discovered in curl that allows an attacker to inject arbitrary Telnet commands via the Telnet option flag (`--telnet-option` in the command line or `CURLOPT_TELNETOPTIONS` in the code) when using three (rarely used) options - `TTYPE`, `XDISPLOC` and `NEW_ENV`.
 
The original report also mentions arbitrary code execution that finally turns out to be impossible. At most, it can only impact applications relying specifically on Telnet options but not the data sent to the server.

Example vulnerable invocation -
`curl --telnet-option NEW_ENV=a,b$(echo -ne "\xff\xf0INJECTED") telnet://server`
The above example will inject the "INJECTED" command

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: As described in the report, the impact and the very rare use of the affected Telnet options make the CVSS inconsistent.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
Attackers must find an input that allows them to insert arbitrary values for the following Telnet options -
* `TTYPE`
* `XDISPLOC`
* `NEW_ENV`
Which is an extremely unlikely scenario

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Telnet is an inherently insecure protocol and an attacker is much more likely to be able to sniff or inject Telnet data using a Man-in-the-middle attack regardless of this vulnerability, which has very rare prerequisites

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: An attacker can inject arbitrary Telnet commands instead of the intended Telnet options

data.summary: An issue in the urllib.parse component of Python before 3.11.4 allows attackers to bypass blocklisting methods by supplying a URL that starts with blank characters.

more_details.description: An issue in the urllib.parse component of Python before 3.11.4 allows attackers to bypass blocklisting methods by supplying a URL that starts with blank characters.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Improper URL parsing in Python can lead to filter bypass when comparing the URL's scheme.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
`urllib.parse` is a widely used module for parsing URLs in Python. One of its core functions, `urlparse`, incorrectly parses URL that start with blank characters, causing any blacklisting methods based on the parsed scheme to fail, as shown in the following example where the `input_scheme` is blank -
```py
from urllib.parse import urlparse

input_scheme = urlparse(" file://127.0.0.1/etc/passwd").scheme
print(input_scheme)
```
The `input_scheme` value is ` ` instead of the expected value of `file`.
high_profile_info.Resolution:
##### Development mitigations

Adding a call to `lstrip` before calling `urlparse` removes the leading blanks, which mitigates the vulnerability - 
```
url = url.lstrip()
...
urlparse(url)
```

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
An attacker must find a remote input that propagates to the `urlparse()` function in which the `scheme` member is accessed.
For example - 
```python
input_scheme = urlparse(attacker_url).scheme
```

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The impact of exploiting the issue depends on the context of surrounding software. A severe impact such as RCE is not guaranteed.
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The security impact of this issue depends on what is done with the parsed scheme of the URL. If the parsed scheme is compared to a blacklist in order to deny specific operations, there may be a security impact when exploiting this issue.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The vulnerability can easily be exploited by adding blank characters at the beginning of the parsed URL

data.summary: In Python (aka CPython) up to 3.10.8, the mailcap module does not add escape characters into commands discovered in the system mailcap file. This may allow attackers to inject shell commands into applications that call mailcap.findmatch with untrusted input (if they lack validation of user-provided filenames or arguments). The fix is also back-ported to 3.7, 3.8, 3.9

more_details.description: In Python (aka CPython) up to 3.10.8, the mailcap module does not add escape characters into commands discovered in the system mailcap file. This may allow attackers to inject shell commands into applications that call mailcap.findmatch with untrusted input (if they lack validation of user-provided filenames or arguments). The fix is also back-ported to 3.7, 3.8, 3.9

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Insufficient input validation in findmatch() function of the Python mailcap module, allows attackers to perform remote code execution.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
The [mailcap](https://docs.python.org/2/library/mailcap.html) library is part of the Python Standard Library ([CPython](https://github.com/python/cpython)). The library is responsible for configuring how MIME-aware applications such as mail readers and Web browsers handle files with different [MIME types](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Media_type). 

The library implementation has a bug in the `mailcap.findmatch()` function, where the `filename` argument is not being sanitized and added as-is to the command line string that is returned from the function. This command line is then usually executed by the application that uses the library to invoke the program that handles the MIME type. If the library is used as a command line tool, this invocation happens automatically by the function `test()` that executes the MIME program automatically to test its return value.

The vulnerability can be exploited if the `findmatch()` function is used and no external user input validation is implemented. In that state, the vulnerability may be exploited by injecting shell commands into the `filename` argument, which will likely be executed later. 

Example of injecting shell command into `filename` argument when using the library in Python code: 
```
commandline, MIMEtype = mailcap.findmatch(
    d, "text/*", filename="'filename; echo HACKED'"
)
os.system(commandline)
```

Example of automatic execution of the injected shell when using the library as a standalone tool:
```
python3 -m mailcap text/html 'filename; echo HACKED'
```

The original issue was discovered in 2015, and although a patch was suggested by a maintainer this year it remained an issue until in 2022 the CVE was published since it was discovered that the `mailcap.findmatch()` function is still exploitable. As a result, the CPython team updated the `mailcap.findmatch()` function to disable ASCII characters other than alphanumerics and `@+=:,./-_` from being injected into the returned command line".
high_profile_info.Resolution:
##### Development mitigations

If possible, avoid using the library for MIME type handling.
If not, sanitize the data that is passed to `filename` parameter of `findmatch()` before calling the function with user-supplied input. It is recommended to sanitize any non-alphanumeric characters to avoid command injections to this argument.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Malicious commands can be easily injected into the `filename` parameter when user-controlled data is passed to it.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are either extremely common or nonexistent (always exploitable)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Applications that use this library, like Email readers or web-content viewers, are likely to process user-controlled data with the vulnerable function, for detecting the program that should handle any kind of MIME type content.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Exploiting this vulnerability can lead to remote code execution when the `filename` argument of `mailcap.findmatch()` is controlled by a user.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
For exploiting this vulnerability, a user should be able to supply input to the `filename` argument of `mailcap.findmatch()`.
Then, the output returned from `findmatch()` function has to be executed as a command line by the application (for example with `os.system()`)
In case the `mailcap` library is used as a command line tool it executes the output automatically.

data.summary: sshd in OpenSSH 6.2 through 8.x before 8.8, when certain non-default configurations are used, allows privilege escalation because supplemental groups are not initialized as expected. Helper programs for AuthorizedKeysCommand and AuthorizedPrincipalsCommand may run with privileges associated with group memberships of the sshd process, if the configuration specifies running the command as a different user.

more_details.description: sshd in OpenSSH 6.2 through 8.x before 8.8, when certain non-default configurations are used, allows privilege escalation because supplemental groups are not initialized as expected. Helper programs for AuthorizedKeysCommand and AuthorizedPrincipalsCommand may run with privileges associated with group memberships of the sshd process, if the configuration specifies running the command as a different user.

data.summary: NULL Pointer Dereference allows attackers to cause a denial of service (or application crash). This only applies when lxml is used together with libxml2 2.9.10 through 2.9.14. libxml2 2.9.9 and earlier are not affected. It allows triggering crashes through forged input data, given a vulnerable code sequence in the application. The vulnerability is caused by the iterwalk function (also used by the canonicalize function). Such code shouldn't be in wide-spread use, given that parsing + iterwalk would usually be replaced with the more efficient iterparse function. However, an XML converter that serialises to C14N would also be vulnerable, for example, and there are legitimate use cases for this code sequence. If untrusted input is received (also remotely) and processed via iterwalk function, a crash can be triggered.

more_details.description: NULL Pointer Dereference allows attackers to cause a denial of service (or application crash). This only applies when lxml is used together with libxml2 2.9.10 through 2.9.14. libxml2 2.9.9 and earlier are not affected. It allows triggering crashes through forged input data, given a vulnerable code sequence in the application. The vulnerability is caused by the iterwalk function (also used by the canonicalize function). Such code shouldn't be in wide-spread use, given that parsing + iterwalk would usually be replaced with the more efficient iterparse function. However, an XML converter that serialises to C14N would also be vulnerable, for example, and there are legitimate use cases for this code sequence. If untrusted input is received (also remotely) and processed via iterwalk function, a crash can be triggered.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Insufficient input validation in lxml Python package leads to denial of service when parsing a crafted XML document with specific lxml functions.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
`libxml2` is a software library for parsing XML documents.
Written in the C programming language, `libxml2` provides bindings to C++, C#, Python, Ruby, Perl, PHP, and more.

`lxml` is a Python package that makes use of `libxml2`.

`XML Namespaces` are used for providing uniquely named elements and attributes in an XML document.
When using prefixes in XML, a namespace for the prefix must be defined.

It was discovered that when parsing a valid XML root tree after parsing an incomplete XML with empty namespace definition, a NULL pointer dereference occurs.
This may lead to denial of service.

The NULL dereference happens in the `vim_appendStartNsEvents()` function defined in the `iterparse.pxi` file of `lxml`.

The vulnerability is caused by the `lxml` `iterwalk()` function (also used by the `canonicalize()` function).
There is a much more efficient and non-vulnerable function `iterparse()` that is more in use, so vulnerable usage is less common.

The root cause of this vulnerability is in `libxml2`.

A parser failure in the first run (parsing an incomplete XML with an empty namespace) had already prepared namespace information when the parsing failed, but did not get cleaned up with the normal reset of the parser context.
The second parse (of a valid XML) passed it on to the second document and `lxml` did not handle it in its code.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
The attacker must find a remote service that parses user-supplied XML input and specifically calls the `canonicalize` or `iterwalk` lxml functions on the parsed XML.
Calling these functions are quite rare since `iterparse` is a much more efficient function that fulfills the same purpose.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: A PoC which triggers NULL dereference is available from the original bug report

data.summary: Python 3.9.x before 3.9.16 and 3.10.x before 3.10.9 on Linux allows local privilege escalation in a non-default configuration. The Python multiprocessing library, when used with the forkserver start method on Linux, allows pickles to be deserialized from any user in the same machine local network namespace, which in many system configurations means any user on the same machine. Pickles can execute arbitrary code. Thus, this allows for local user privilege escalation to the user that any forkserver process is running as. Setting multiprocessing.util.abstract_sockets_supported to False is a workaround. The forkserver start method for multiprocessing is not the default start method. This issue is Linux specific because only Linux supports abstract namespace sockets. CPython before 3.9 does not make use of Linux abstract namespace sockets by default. Support for users manually specifying an abstract namespace socket was added as a bugfix in 3.7.8 and 3.8.3, but users would need to make specific uncommon API calls in order to do that in CPython before 3.9.

more_details.description: Python 3.9.x before 3.9.16 and 3.10.x before 3.10.9 on Linux allows local privilege escalation in a non-default configuration. The Python multiprocessing library, when used with the forkserver start method on Linux, allows pickles to be deserialized from any user in the same machine local network namespace, which in many system configurations means any user on the same machine. Pickles can execute arbitrary code. Thus, this allows for local user privilege escalation to the user that any forkserver process is running as. Setting multiprocessing.util.abstract_sockets_supported to False is a workaround. The forkserver start method for multiprocessing is not the default start method. This issue is Linux specific because only Linux supports abstract namespace sockets. CPython before 3.9 does not make use of Linux abstract namespace sockets by default. Support for users manually specifying an abstract namespace socket was added as a bugfix in 3.7.8 and 3.8.3, but users would need to make specific uncommon API calls in order to do that in CPython before 3.9.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Insufficient permissions check in Python 3.7, 3.8, 3.9 and 3.10 on Linux may lead to privilege escalation when using the non-default 'forkserver' start method of the 'multiprocessing' module.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
Python `multiprocessing` is a package that supports spawning processes using an API similar to the threading module. It supports three ways to start a process: `spawn`,`fork`, and `forkserver`.

It was discovered that the library, when used with the `forkserver` start method on Linux, can result in local privilege escalation.

This may happen when the `forkserver` is using Linux abstract namespace sockets, which is the default on Linux in Python 3.9 and Python 3.10.
Linux abstract sockets lack any form of permissions so their use allows any process in the same host-local network namespace (which means any user on the system in many default configurations) to communicate with them.

The `forkserver` is deserializing Python pickles being sent on those sockets, and pickles can execute code.

Therefore, this allows local user privilege escalation to the user that any Python multiprocessing `forkserver` process is running.

The `forkserver` start method for multiprocessing is not the default start method. This issue is Linux specific because only Linux supports abstract namespace sockets.

Although in Python 3.9 and 3.10 Linux abstract namespace sockets are the default communication method with the `forkserver`, it is not the default in Python 3.7 and 3.8.
Support for users manually specifying an abstract namespace socket was added as a [bugfix](https://github.com/python/cpython/issues/84031) in 3.7.8 and 3.8.3, but users would need to make specific uncommon multiprocessing API calls specifying their own `forkserver` control socket path in order to do that in Python before 3.9 - which makes the applicability of this CVE very rare in Python 3.8 and 3.7.
high_profile_info.Resolution:
##### Development mitigations

Remove these two lines from CPython's Lib/multiprocessing/connection.py:
```
if util.abstract_sockets_supported:
   return f"\0listener-{os.getpid()}-{next(_mmap_counter)}"
```

##### Development mitigations

From python application or library code:
```
import multiprocessing.util
multiprocessing.util.abstract_sockets_supported = False
```

This disables abstract sockets use by default. You must execute that before anything else in your process.


Alternatives to avoid the problem:
If your Linux Python application can be switched from multiprocessing's `.set_start_method("forkserver")` to a start method such as `"spawn"` that will also avoid this issue.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
* Only applies to code that uses the multiprocessing module.
* Only applies when the code uses the non-default 'forkserver' start method, and the 'forkserver' needs to still be up (e.g. do complex work).
* On Python 3.7 and Python 3.8- this only applies to code that specifies an abstract socket to use.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: JFrog Security Research has developed a private exploit for this issue which is available on request.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue can only be exploited by an attacker that can execute code on the vulnerable machine (excluding exceedingly rare circumstances)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Exploitation allows to execute code as the user running the `forkserver`.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue can be exploited by an unauthenticated attacker or an attacker with low privileges
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The attack can be carried out by an arbitrary local attacker since abstract sockets are used, which in many system configurations means any user on the same machine can communicate with them.

ExtendedReferences.Title: GitHub Issue explaining the problem with patch commits.

data.summary: The legacy email.utils.parseaddr function in Python through 3.11.4 allows attackers to trigger "RecursionError: maximum recursion depth exceeded while calling a Python object" via a crafted argument. This argument is plausibly an untrusted value from an application's input data that was supposed to contain a name and an e-mail address. NOTE: email.utils.parseaddr is categorized as a Legacy API in the documentation of the Python email package. Applications should instead use the email.parser.BytesParser or email.parser.Parser class.

more_details.description: The legacy email.utils.parseaddr function in Python through 3.11.4 allows attackers to trigger "RecursionError: maximum recursion depth exceeded while calling a Python object" via a crafted argument. This argument is plausibly an untrusted value from an application's input data that was supposed to contain a name and an e-mail address. NOTE: email.utils.parseaddr is categorized as a Legacy API in the documentation of the Python email package. Applications should instead use the email.parser.BytesParser or email.parser.Parser class.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: (Non-Issue) Improper parsing of email addresses in Python's built-in email module can lead to denial of service.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has been disputed by the vendor
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The purpose of the email package is to impose size limitations and generate an exception when those limits are surpassed, thus this issue is not a security issue but rather the intended functionality of the package. The thrown exception should be caught by the users of this package.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
A PoC has been published in the original report:

```
from email.utils import parseaddr
parseaddr(':' * 100000)
```

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Attacker must determine which remote input propagates to `email.utils.parseaddr()`.

data.summary: The legacy email.utils.parseaddr function in Python through 3.11.4 allows attackers to trigger "RecursionError: maximum recursion depth exceeded while calling a Python object" via a crafted argument. This argument is plausibly an untrusted value from an application's input data that was supposed to contain a name and an e-mail address. NOTE: email.utils.parseaddr is categorized as a Legacy API in the documentation of the Python email package. Applications should instead use the email.parser.BytesParser or email.parser.Parser class.

NOTE: email.utils.parseaddr is categorized as a Legacy API in the documentation of the Python email package. Applications should instead use the email.parser.BytesParser or email.parser.Parser class.

data.summary: ncurses before 6.4 20230408, when used by a setuid application, allows local users to trigger security-relevant memory corruption via malformed data in a terminfo database file that is found in $HOME/.terminfo or reached via the TERMINFO or TERM environment variable.

more_details.description: ncurses before 6.4 20230408, when used by a setuid application, allows local users to trigger security-relevant memory corruption via malformed data in a terminfo database file that is found in $HOME/.terminfo or reached via the TERMINFO or TERM environment variable.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: A heap buffer overflow in ncurses may lead to local privilege escalation when a setuid application parses a crafted terminfo database.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
ncurses is a programming library that allows developers to create text-based user interfaces in a terminal or console window. It provides functions for controlling the cursor, displaying text and graphics, and handling user input, and is widely used in Unix-like operating systems for building cross-platform command-line applications.
The `terminfo` file is a database that stores information about terminal types and their capabilities.  By default, ncurses will search `${HOME}/.terminfo` first, then `/etc/terminfo`, then `/lib/terminfo`, and
 finally `/usr/share/terminfo`.

Terminfo allows to declare user definable attributes, custom numbers or strings thatextend its standard capabilities.
Users can customize their own terminfo definitions by creating or modifying files within their `.terminfo`. 
The `.terminfo` directory is typically located at `$HOME/.terminfo`, and users have the necessary privileges to modify the files within this directory. The default location can be overwritten by defining the `$TERMINFO` or `$TERM` environment variable.
Example: `export TERMINFO=/my/terminfo/db/path`

An issue was discovered in the ncurses library's `_nc_read_termtype` function, responsible for parsing terminfo database file due to improper handling of heap allocation for `Strings` and `Extended Strings` within the `terminfo` file. The function fails to handle the allocation correctly, leading to a heap buffer overflow, which can result in memory corruption issues.
Due to the nature of the vulnerability, an attacker would mainly try to get local privilege escalation. Then, the only binaries that are vulnerable to this issue are the `SetUID binaries` that are using `ncurses`. 
 
The exposed functions that call the `_nc_read_termtype` function are: `_nc_read_file_entry`, `initscr`, `setupterm` and `resttarterm` functions.

Note that this issue can also be triggered by the ncurses's progs tools like `infocmp` and `tic`. However, they're not `setuid` binaries so they cannot be used for a privilege escalation.
high_profile_info.Resolution:
##### Deployment mitigations

Make the `TERMINFO` environment variable and the default user-controlled terminfo database file un-writeable:

1. Identify the shell configuration file for the different user account in the system. The shell configuration file depends on the user's shell. Common examples include `.bashrc` for `Bash`, `.bash_profile` for `Bash login shells`, and `.profile` for `POSIX-compliant shells`. The file is typically located in the user's home directory.
2. Open the file with `root` access
3. Add the following line to make the TERMINFO environment variable un-writtable: 
```
export TERMINFO=
readonly TERMINFO
```
4. Still with `root` access, create an empty `.terminfo` file in the home directory of the user:
```
touch $HOME/.terminfo
```

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The CVSS score does not reflect the real-world impact of the issue, since the issue cannot be exploited by an external attacker.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: A crashing exploit including a technical write-up was published.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue can only be exploited by an attacker that can execute code on the vulnerable machine (excluding exceedingly rare circumstances)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: This issue can only be exploited for privilege escalation by running a setuid application using ncurses locally on the victim system.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
The issue requires the following:
1. The attackers must have access to the system on a low-permission user.
2. Be able to download or create a malicious terminfo database file.
3. Set the `$TERMINFO` environment variable.
4. Lastly, a `setuid` binary that uses the ncurses library should be accessible to them.

data.summary: Integer Overflow or Wraparound in GitHub repository vim/vim prior to 9.0.1532.

more_details.description: Integer Overflow or Wraparound in GitHub repository vim/vim prior to 9.0.1532.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: (Non-Issue) Buffer overflow in vim leads to denial of service and potentially code execution when running crafted vim commands.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Vim](https://www.vim.org/) is a free, open-source, screen-based text editor program for Unix.
Vim has an `Ex mode` that allows entering Ex commands and is designed for Batch processing.

The Ex, or colon, commands are based on the line editor named ex. In general, they operate on the document as a whole, or large portions of it (although there are commands to perform essentially every editing task).

It was discovered that when sourcing a file using Vim `Ex mode`, a heap overflow may occur, which leads to a denial of service.

`vim` can be run with one or more flags. These flags include, but are not limited to:

* `-e`: With the `-e` flag, the user enters Ex mode. The Ex mode is similar to the command line mode as it also allows you to enter Ex commands.
* `-s`: With the `-s` flag, the user can silence the ex mode, to support batch commands.
* `-S`: With the `-S` flag, the user sources the file after loading it.

The issue requires the victim to run an attacker's specially crafted file in `Ex mode` and source it as well.
An example of a vulnerable command line:
`vim -e -s -S {malicious_file}`

Opening files with vim in this specific mode is highly unlikely.

This vulnerability has no security impact at all since if an attacker can run arbitrary vim commands, then the attacker can also execute arbitrary shell commands using the exclamation mark, and does not need this vulnerability to achieve code execution. For example running the vim command `!ls` will execute the shell command `ls`.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The CVSS does not reflect the contextual prerequisites required to exploit the vulnerability.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploiting the issue requires the user to interact with the vulnerable software
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The victim must open the attacker's crafted text file in Vim.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: An exploit has been published along with the original report.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: This vulnerability has no security impact since if an attacker can run arbitrary vim commands, then the attacker can also execute arbitrary shell commands using the exclamation mark, and does not need this vulnerability to achieve code execution.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: To exploit this issue Vim must be run in `Ex mode` and also source the malicious text file.

data.summary: A vulnerability in input validation exists in curl <8.0 during communication using the TELNET protocol may allow an attacker to pass on maliciously crafted user name and "telnet options" during server negotiation. The lack of proper input scrubbing allows an attacker to send content or perform option negotiation without the application's intent. This vulnerability could be exploited if an application allows user input, thereby enabling attackers to execute arbitrary code on the system.

more_details.description: A vulnerability in input validation exists in curl <8.0 during communication using the TELNET protocol may allow an attacker to pass on maliciously crafted user name and "telnet options" during server negotiation. The lack of proper input scrubbing allows an attacker to send content or perform option negotiation without the application's intent. This vulnerability could be exploited if an application allows user input, thereby enabling attackers to execute arbitrary code on the system.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Improper command sanitization in curl can lead to content passing through specific options when telnet is enabled.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Curl](https://curl.se/) is a command-line tool for transferring data from or to a server, using various protocols like HTTP, FTP, SMTP, and more.
An issue has been discovered in curl that allows an attacker to inject arbitrary Telnet commands via the Telnet option flag (`--telnet-option` in the command line or `CURLOPT_TELNETOPTIONS` in the code) when using three (rarely used) options - `TTYPE`, `XDISPLOC` and `NEW_ENV`.
 
The original report also mentions arbitrary code execution that finally turns out to be impossible. At most, it can only impact applications relying specifically on Telnet options but not the data sent to the server.

Example vulnerable invocation -
`curl --telnet-option NEW_ENV=a,b$(echo -ne "\xff\xf0INJECTED") telnet://server`
The above example will inject the "INJECTED" command

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: As described in the report, the impact and the very rare use of the affected Telnet options make the CVSS inconsistent.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
Attackers must find an input that allows them to insert arbitrary values for the following Telnet options -
* `TTYPE`
* `XDISPLOC`
* `NEW_ENV`
Which is an extremely unlikely scenario

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Telnet is an inherently insecure protocol and an attacker is much more likely to be able to sniff or inject Telnet data using a Man-in-the-middle attack regardless of this vulnerability, which has very rare prerequisites

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: An attacker can inject arbitrary Telnet commands instead of the intended Telnet options

more_details.description: Integer Overflow or Wraparound in GitHub repository vim/vim prior to 9.0.1532.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: (Non-Issue) Buffer overflow in vim leads to denial of service and potentially code execution when running crafted vim commands.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Vim](https://www.vim.org/) is a free, open-source, screen-based text editor program for Unix.
Vim has an `Ex mode` that allows entering Ex commands and is designed for Batch processing.

The Ex, or colon, commands are based on the line editor named ex. In general, they operate on the document as a whole, or large portions of it (although there are commands to perform essentially every editing task).

It was discovered that when sourcing a file using Vim `Ex mode`, a heap overflow may occur, which leads to a denial of service.

`vim` can be run with one or more flags. These flags include, but are not limited to:

* `-e`: With the `-e` flag, the user enters Ex mode. The Ex mode is similar to the command line mode as it also allows you to enter Ex commands.
* `-s`: With the `-s` flag, the user can silence the ex mode, to support batch commands.
* `-S`: With the `-S` flag, the user sources the file after loading it.

The issue requires the victim to run an attacker's specially crafted file in `Ex mode` and source it as well.
An example of a vulnerable command line:
`vim -e -s -S {malicious_file}`

Opening files with vim in this specific mode is highly unlikely.

This vulnerability has no security impact at all since if an attacker can run arbitrary vim commands, then the attacker can also execute arbitrary shell commands using the exclamation mark, and does not need this vulnerability to achieve code execution. For example running the vim command `!ls` will execute the shell command `ls`.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The CVSS does not reflect the contextual prerequisites required to exploit the vulnerability.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploiting the issue requires the user to interact with the vulnerable software
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The victim must open the attacker's crafted text file in Vim.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: An exploit has been published along with the original report.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: This vulnerability has no security impact since if an attacker can run arbitrary vim commands, then the attacker can also execute arbitrary shell commands using the exclamation mark, and does not need this vulnerability to achieve code execution.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: To exploit this issue Vim must be run in `Ex mode` and also source the malicious text file.

data.summary: A flaw was found in python. In algorithms with quadratic time complexity using non-binary bases, when using int("text"), a system could take 50ms to parse an int string with 100,000 digits and 5s for 1,000,000 digits (float, decimal, int.from_bytes(), and int() for binary bases 2, 4, 8, 16, and 32 are not affected). The highest threat from this vulnerability is to system availability.

more_details.description: A flaw was found in python. In algorithms with quadratic time complexity using non-binary bases, when using int("text"), a system could take 50ms to parse an int string with 100,000 digits and 5s for 1,000,000 digits (float, decimal, int.from_bytes(), and int() for binary bases 2, 4, 8, 16, and 32 are not affected). The highest threat from this vulnerability is to system availability.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Inefficient algorithm in Python integer parsing leads to denial of service when converting user-supplied integer strings.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
Python contains the built-in `int()` and `str()` functions which enable integer conversion to and from strings. To be able to convert a big number, Python uses an algorithm with a quadratic complexity.

A long string could cause a very long time response and then makes the system unavailable for a long time.
For example -
```py
>>> n = 10**(10**7) 
>>> s = str(n)  # expect instant ValueError, but takes many minutes
```

Or alternatively -
```py
>>> s = "1'+'0'*1000000
>>> i = int(s)  # expect instant ValueError, but takes many minutes
```

Currently, no fixed versions of Python are available since this issue is still in discussion

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The attacker must continuously repeat the attack to gain a persistent DoS

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
Example making the system unavailable for many minutes -
```py
>>> n = 10**(10**7)  # takes a few seconds to run 
>>> s = str(n)  # expect instant ValueError, but takes many minutes
```

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The attacker must find an input that propagates into the `int()` or `str()` methods,  without any limit on the given integer/string

data.summary: Python 3.9.x before 3.9.16 and 3.10.x before 3.10.9 on Linux allows local privilege escalation in a non-default configuration. The Python multiprocessing library, when used with the forkserver start method on Linux, allows pickles to be deserialized from any user in the same machine local network namespace, which in many system configurations means any user on the same machine. Pickles can execute arbitrary code. Thus, this allows for local user privilege escalation to the user that any forkserver process is running as. Setting multiprocessing.util.abstract_sockets_supported to False is a workaround. The forkserver start method for multiprocessing is not the default start method. This issue is Linux specific because only Linux supports abstract namespace sockets. CPython before 3.9 does not make use of Linux abstract namespace sockets by default. Support for users manually specifying an abstract namespace socket was added as a bugfix in 3.7.8 and 3.8.3, but users would need to make specific uncommon API calls in order to do that in CPython before 3.9.

more_details.description: Python 3.9.x before 3.9.16 and 3.10.x before 3.10.9 on Linux allows local privilege escalation in a non-default configuration. The Python multiprocessing library, when used with the forkserver start method on Linux, allows pickles to be deserialized from any user in the same machine local network namespace, which in many system configurations means any user on the same machine. Pickles can execute arbitrary code. Thus, this allows for local user privilege escalation to the user that any forkserver process is running as. Setting multiprocessing.util.abstract_sockets_supported to False is a workaround. The forkserver start method for multiprocessing is not the default start method. This issue is Linux specific because only Linux supports abstract namespace sockets. CPython before 3.9 does not make use of Linux abstract namespace sockets by default. Support for users manually specifying an abstract namespace socket was added as a bugfix in 3.7.8 and 3.8.3, but users would need to make specific uncommon API calls in order to do that in CPython before 3.9.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Insufficient permissions check in Python 3.7, 3.8, 3.9 and 3.10 on Linux may lead to privilege escalation when using the non-default 'forkserver' start method of the 'multiprocessing' module.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
Python `multiprocessing` is a package that supports spawning processes using an API similar to the threading module. It supports three ways to start a process: `spawn`,`fork`, and `forkserver`.

It was discovered that the library, when used with the `forkserver` start method on Linux, can result in local privilege escalation.

This may happen when the `forkserver` is using Linux abstract namespace sockets, which is the default on Linux in Python 3.9 and Python 3.10.
Linux abstract sockets lack any form of permissions so their use allows any process in the same host-local network namespace (which means any user on the system in many default configurations) to communicate with them.

The `forkserver` is deserializing Python pickles being sent on those sockets, and pickles can execute code.

Therefore, this allows local user privilege escalation to the user that any Python multiprocessing `forkserver` process is running.

The `forkserver` start method for multiprocessing is not the default start method. This issue is Linux specific because only Linux supports abstract namespace sockets.

Although in Python 3.9 and 3.10 Linux abstract namespace sockets are the default communication method with the `forkserver`, it is not the default in Python 3.7 and 3.8.
Support for users manually specifying an abstract namespace socket was added as a [bugfix](https://github.com/python/cpython/issues/84031) in 3.7.8 and 3.8.3, but users would need to make specific uncommon multiprocessing API calls specifying their own `forkserver` control socket path in order to do that in Python before 3.9 - which makes the applicability of this CVE very rare in Python 3.8 and 3.7.
high_profile_info.Resolution:
##### Development mitigations

Remove these two lines from CPython's Lib/multiprocessing/connection.py:
```
if util.abstract_sockets_supported:
   return f"\0listener-{os.getpid()}-{next(_mmap_counter)}"
```

##### Development mitigations

From python application or library code:
```
import multiprocessing.util
multiprocessing.util.abstract_sockets_supported = False
```

This disables abstract sockets use by default. You must execute that before anything else in your process.


Alternatives to avoid the problem:
If your Linux Python application can be switched from multiprocessing's `.set_start_method("forkserver")` to a start method such as `"spawn"` that will also avoid this issue.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
* Only applies to code that uses the multiprocessing module.
* Only applies when the code uses the non-default 'forkserver' start method, and the 'forkserver' needs to still be up (e.g. do complex work).
* On Python 3.7 and Python 3.8- this only applies to code that specifies an abstract socket to use.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: JFrog Security Research has developed a private exploit for this issue which is available on request.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue can only be exploited by an attacker that can execute code on the vulnerable machine (excluding exceedingly rare circumstances)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Exploitation allows to execute code as the user running the `forkserver`.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue can be exploited by an unauthenticated attacker or an attacker with low privileges
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The attack can be carried out by an arbitrary local attacker since abstract sockets are used, which in many system configurations means any user on the same machine can communicate with them.

ExtendedReferences.Title: GitHub Issue explaining the problem with patch commits.

data.summary: An out-of-bounds read/write vulnerability was found in e2fsprogs 1.46.5. This issue leads to a segmentation fault and possibly arbitrary code execution via a specially crafted filesystem.

more_details.description: An out-of-bounds read/write vulnerability was found in e2fsprogs 1.46.5. This issue leads to a segmentation fault and possibly arbitrary code execution via a specially crafted filesystem.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: An out-of-bounds write in e2fsck can lead to local privilege escalation when processing a crafted filesystem image.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[e2fsprogs](http://e2fsprogs.sourceforge.net/) is a set of utilities for maintaining the ext2, ext3 and ext4 file systems. Since those file systems are often the default for Linux distributions, it is commonly considered to be essential software.

A crafted malicious filesystem can cause a segmentation fault and arbitrary code execution in e2fsprogs. 

However, the attacker should either find an input that propagates and turns out to be passed to the `e2fsck` tool or use another vulnerability to upload the malicious filesystem image and find a way to pass it to `e2fsck`.

It’s highly unlikely a remote service would use the `e2fsck` tool on externally supplied input.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue can only be exploited by an attacker that can execute code on the vulnerable machine (excluding exceedingly rare circumstances)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The attack must be performed locally, as it’s highly unlikely a remote service would use the `e2fsck` tool on externally supplied input.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The Denial-of-Service impact is mitigated since the only known attack vector is by running a forked process (`e2fsck`). Crashing a forked client process is usually not a severe impact. Also, the e2fsprogs tools are userland utilities, thus not affecting the kernel and cannot lead to a container escape.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: A Proof-of-Concept which leads to a Denial-of-Service was published by the reporting researcher.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploiting the issue requires the user to interact with the vulnerable software
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Requires the user to run the `e2fsck` tool on a crafted filesystem.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The attacker must be able to put a crafted filesystem image on the target filesystem and have a privileged user execute the `e2fsck` tool on this image.

data.summary: An out-of-bounds read/write vulnerability was found in e2fsprogs 1.46.5. This issue leads to a segmentation fault and possibly arbitrary code execution via a specially crafted filesystem.

more_details.description: An out-of-bounds read/write vulnerability was found in e2fsprogs 1.46.5. This issue leads to a segmentation fault and possibly arbitrary code execution via a specially crafted filesystem.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: An out-of-bounds write in e2fsck can lead to local privilege escalation when processing a crafted filesystem image.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[e2fsprogs](http://e2fsprogs.sourceforge.net/) is a set of utilities for maintaining the ext2, ext3 and ext4 file systems. Since those file systems are often the default for Linux distributions, it is commonly considered to be essential software.

A crafted malicious filesystem can cause a segmentation fault and arbitrary code execution in e2fsprogs. 

However, the attacker should either find an input that propagates and turns out to be passed to the `e2fsck` tool or use another vulnerability to upload the malicious filesystem image and find a way to pass it to `e2fsck`.

It’s highly unlikely a remote service would use the `e2fsck` tool on externally supplied input.

data.summary: A flaw was found in the bash package, where a heap-buffer overflow can occur in valid parameter_transform. This issue may lead to memory problems.

more_details.description: A flaw was found in the bash package, where a heap-buffer overflow can occur in valid parameter_transform. This issue may lead to memory problems.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Out-of-bound read in Bash can lead to denial of service when processing a crafted parameter expansion.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Bash](https://www.gnu.org/software/bash/) is a Unix shell, which is a command-line interface for interacting with an operating system. It is the default shell for most Linux distributions. Bash allows users to execute commands, manipulate files, and run scripts to automate tasks.

When bash is compiled with [ASAN (AdressSanitizer)](https://github.com/google/sanitizers/wiki/AddressSanitizer), a script using a crafted [Shell parameter expansion](https://www.gnu.org/software/bash/manual/html_node/Shell-Parameter-Expansion.html) of type `${parameter@operator}` can lead to out-of-bound read of 1 byte. 
In some circumstances (ex. Bash is compiled with ASAN) this can crash the bash process, but triggering a crash is unlikely in real-world scenarios.

The attackers must find a remote input that propagates to a bash script using this special parameter expansion which is not easy at all and very unlikely.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Attackers can simply create a parameter transformation on a variable that contains the same parameter transformation

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: In some circumstances (ex. Bash is compiled with ASAN) exploiting this issue can crash the bash process, but triggering a crash is unlikely in real-world scenarios.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
The attackers must find a remote input that propagates to a bash script using the special parameter expansion `${parameter@operator}` where the parameter is taken from a user-controlled input. 
This is extremely unlikely to happen in a remote scenario.

data.summary: Git is a revision control system. Prior to versions 2.30.9, 2.31.8, 2.32.7, 2.33.8, 2.34.8, 2.35.8, 2.36.6, 2.37.7, 2.38.5, 2.39.3, and 2.40.1, a specially crafted `.gitmodules` file with submodule URLs that are longer than 1024 characters can used to exploit a bug in `config.c::git_config_copy_or_rename_section_in_file()`. This bug can be used to inject arbitrary configuration into a user's `$GIT_DIR/config` when attempting to remove the configuration section associated with that submodule. When the attacker injects configuration values which specify executables to run (such as `core.pager`, `core.editor`, `core.sshCommand`, etc.) this can lead to a remote code execution. A fix A fix is available in versions 2.30.9, 2.31.8, 2.32.7, 2.33.8, 2.34.8, 2.35.8, 2.36.6, 2.37.7, 2.38.5, 2.39.3, and 2.40.1. As a workaround, avoid running `git submodule deinit` on untrusted repositories or without prior inspection of any submodule sections in `$GIT_DIR/config`.

more_details.description: Git is a revision control system. Prior to versions 2.30.9, 2.31.8, 2.32.7, 2.33.8, 2.34.8, 2.35.8, 2.36.6, 2.37.7, 2.38.5, 2.39.3, and 2.40.1, a specially crafted `.gitmodules` file with submodule URLs that are longer than 1024 characters can used to exploit a bug in `config.c::git_config_copy_or_rename_section_in_file()`. This bug can be used to inject arbitrary configuration into a user's `$GIT_DIR/config` when attempting to remove the configuration section associated with that submodule. When the attacker injects configuration values which specify executables to run (such as `core.pager`, `core.editor`, `core.sshCommand`, etc.) this can lead to a remote code execution. A fix A fix is available in versions 2.30.9, 2.31.8, 2.32.7, 2.33.8, 2.34.8, 2.35.8, 2.36.6, 2.37.7, 2.38.5, 2.39.3, and 2.40.1. As a workaround, avoid running `git submodule deinit` on untrusted repositories or without prior inspection of any submodule sections in `$GIT_DIR/config`.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: A design problem in Git may lead to arbitrary configuration injection and possibly to remote code execution when processing crafted repositories.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploiting the issue requires the user to interact with the vulnerable software
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: To exploit this vulnerability the user must run one of the following legitimate git commands, after initializing a malicious submodule: `git submodule deinit`, `git config --rename-section`, or `git config --remove-section`.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
The attacker must craft the `.gitmodules ` file and push it to a Git repository that the victim machine or user would clone or pull.
Also, the attacker needs to convince the user initialize a submodule and then run one of the git commands that trigger the issue using a crafted error message.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The published PoC demonstrates remote code execution.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Exploiting the issue might lead to remote code execution.
