data.summary: Libgcrypt before 1.8.8 and 1.9.x before 1.9.3 mishandles ElGamal encryption because it lacks exponent blinding to address a side-channel attack against mpi_powm, and the window size is not chosen appropriately. This, for example, affects use of ElGamal in OpenPGP.

more_details.description: Libgcrypt before 1.8.8 and 1.9.x before 1.9.3 mishandles ElGamal encryption because it lacks exponent blinding to address a side-channel attack against mpi_powm, and the window size is not chosen appropriately. This, for example, affects use of ElGamal in OpenPGP.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Timing data leak in libgcrypt ElGamal encryption can lead to key brute force when attackers can cause many decryption operations.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Libgcrypt](https://gnupg.org/software/libgcrypt/index.html) is a general-purpose cryptographic library based on the code from GnuPG.
[ElGamal encryption](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ElGamal_encryption) is a public-key cryptosystem that is widely used in OpenPGP for key management and encrypted communication.

In ElGamal encryption, the encryption operation involves raising a message to the power of the public key. An attacker might be able to perform a timing attack to extract information about the private key by observing the time it takes to perform the encryption.

To perform this attack, an attacker would need to be on the same machine or subnet where the decryption takes place, and be able to trigger many decryption operations (oracle attack).

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The attacker would need to be able to trigger many decryption operations (oracle attack).

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: ElGamal is rarely used alone (used more as part of a hybrid encryption type)

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue can only be exploited by an attacker that can execute code on the vulnerable machine (excluding exceedingly rare circumstances)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Due to the nature of timing attacks, the attack would be much more successful by an attacker that can already run code on the machine that performs the decryption. At most, the attacker needs to be on the same subnet as the decryption machine.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has a detailed technical explanation published, that can aid in exploit development
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The paper gives all the details to exploit this issue.

data.summary: CPAN 2.28 allows Signature Verification Bypass.

more_details.description: CPAN 2.28 allows Signature Verification Bypass.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Improper validation logic in CPAN leads to signature validation bypass when installing a module from an untrusted CPAN mirror.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[CPAN](https://www.cpan.org/) (Comprehensive Perl Archive Network) is a repository of over 200,000 modules for the Perl programming language. 

To install Perl modules from CPAN, users can use either the `cpan` client provided by [CPAN.pm](https://metacpan.org/dist/CPAN) (included in the Perl core) or the `cpanm` client provided by [cpanminus](https://metacpan.org/pod/App::cpanminus).

When downloading a module, the cpan client retrieves a tarball with an encrypted `CHECKSUMS` file. The client generates its own local `CHECKSUMS` file for the downloaded file and compares it to the downloaded CHECKSUMS file. **By default**, the client only compares the `CHECKSUMS` files content but **does not validate the authenticity of the downloaded `CHECKSUMS` file**. To enable this option in cpan, the user can run the following command: `o conf check_sigs 1` and to make the changes persistent, run `o conf commit` after the first command.

However, even when signature checking is enabled, there is a flaw in the `CHECKSUMS` file validation logic. An attacker can add a prepended checksum for a modified package to the beginning of the `CHECKSUMS` file, which will cause the `Module::Signature::_verify()` function to pass and trigger the installation even though the return code is `CANNOT_VERIFY`, which will be considered as `SIGNATURE_OK`.

This issue can be used to carry out supply chain attacks, as demonstrated in the [PoC](https://blog.hackeriet.no/cpan-signature-verification-vulnerabilities/). The attacker must create their own CPAN mirror, change the targeted module to add its malicious behaviors, calculate the new checksums from its files and add the calculated checksum to the beginning of the associated `CHECKSUMS` file.
high_profile_info.Resolution:
##### Deployment mitigations

Use the official CPAN HTTPS mirror, by running the following command `o conf urllist https://www.cpan.org` followed by `o conf commit` persist the configuration.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Adding a mirror server on CPAN is very unlikely to happen.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The published PoC demonstrates how to calculate the new checksum and add it to the `CHECKSUMS` file of the module, allowing malicious code to be easily added.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploiting the issue requires the user to interact with the vulnerable software
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The user must add the untrusted mirror in the cpan mirror list and choose to install a module

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Untrusted code execution due to signature bypass

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has a detailed technical explanation published, that can aid in exploit development

ExtendedReferences.Title: Technical write-up with a PoC demonstrating a signature verification bypass using an attack-controlled mirror.
Perl official advisory with additional details.

data.summary: CPAN 2.28 allows Signature Verification Bypass.

more_details.description: CPAN 2.28 allows Signature Verification Bypass.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Improper validation logic in CPAN leads to signature validation bypass when installing a module from an untrusted CPAN mirror.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[CPAN](https://www.cpan.org/) (Comprehensive Perl Archive Network) is a repository of over 200,000 modules for the Perl programming language. 

To install Perl modules from CPAN, users can use either the `cpan` client provided by [CPAN.pm](https://metacpan.org/dist/CPAN) (included in the Perl core) or the `cpanm` client provided by [cpanminus](https://metacpan.org/pod/App::cpanminus).

When downloading a module, the cpan client retrieves a tarball with an encrypted `CHECKSUMS` file. The client generates its own local `CHECKSUMS` file for the downloaded file and compares it to the downloaded CHECKSUMS file. **By default**, the client only compares the `CHECKSUMS` files content but **does not validate the authenticity of the downloaded `CHECKSUMS` file**. To enable this option in cpan, the user can run the following command: `o conf check_sigs 1` and to make the changes persistent, run `o conf commit` after the first command.

However, even when signature checking is enabled, there is a flaw in the `CHECKSUMS` file validation logic. An attacker can add a prepended checksum for a modified package to the beginning of the `CHECKSUMS` file, which will cause the `Module::Signature::_verify()` function to pass and trigger the installation even though the return code is `CANNOT_VERIFY`, which will be considered as `SIGNATURE_OK`.

This issue can be used to carry out supply chain attacks, as demonstrated in the [PoC](https://blog.hackeriet.no/cpan-signature-verification-vulnerabilities/). The attacker must create their own CPAN mirror, change the targeted module to add its malicious behaviors, calculate the new checksums from its files and add the calculated checksum to the beginning of the associated `CHECKSUMS` file.
high_profile_info.Resolution:
##### Deployment mitigations

Use the official CPAN HTTPS mirror, by running the following command `o conf urllist https://www.cpan.org` followed by `o conf commit` persist the configuration.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Adding a mirror server on CPAN is very unlikely to happen.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The published PoC demonstrates how to calculate the new checksum and add it to the `CHECKSUMS` file of the module, allowing malicious code to be easily added.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploiting the issue requires the user to interact with the vulnerable software
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The user must add the untrusted mirror in the cpan mirror list and choose to install a module

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Untrusted code execution due to signature bypass

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has a detailed technical explanation published, that can aid in exploit development

ExtendedReferences.Title: Technical write-up with a PoC demonstrating a signature verification bypass using an attack-controlled mirror.
Perl official advisory with additional details.

data.summary: A vulnerability was found in zstd v1.4.10, where an attacker can supply empty string as an argument to the command line tool to cause buffer overrun.

more_details.description: A vulnerability was found in zstd v1.4.10, where an attacker can supply empty string as an argument to the command line tool to cause buffer overrun.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Out-of-bounds read in zstd may lead denial of service when using crafted command-line arguments.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Zstandard](https://facebook.github.io/zstd/) is a fast lossless compression algorithm, providing high compression ratios and targeting real-time compression scenarios at zlib-level.
`zstd` is the reference implementation in C that offers a very wide range of speed / compression trade-off, and is backed by an extremely fast decoder.
It was discovered that running the `zstd` tool with arbitrary arguments can lead to an OOB read due to a design flaw, which may lead to a crash of `zstd`. Since `zstd` is a standalone (forked) tool - the crash has a minimal security impact.

Specifically, passing the `--output-dir-flat` or `--output-dir-mirror` arguments with an empty string, leads to an OOB read.

It should be noted that the OOB read is of 1 byte only, which on modern systems does not even lead to a crash (in most cases of production-built software)

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The CVSS does not take into account the high attack complexity and low real-world severity of this issue

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Crashing a forked process has minimal to no security impact. Furthermore, a 1-byte OOB read will not lead to a crash in almost all cases.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Passing an empty string to the flags "--output-dir-flat" or "--output-dir-mirror" will trigger the 1-byte OOB read

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The attacker must be able to supply command line arguments to an invocation of the `zstd` CLI tool.

data.summary: An issue was discovered in rsync before 3.2.5 that allows malicious remote servers to write arbitrary files inside the directories of connecting peers. The server chooses which files/directories are sent to the client. However, the rsync client performs insufficient validation of file names. A malicious rsync server (or Man-in-The-Middle attacker) can overwrite arbitrary files in the rsync client target directory and subdirectories (for example, overwrite the .ssh/authorized_keys file).

more_details.description: An issue was discovered in rsync before 3.2.5 that allows malicious remote servers to write arbitrary files inside the directories of connecting peers. The server chooses which files/directories are sent to the client. However, the rsync client performs insufficient validation of file names. A malicious rsync server (or Man-in-The-Middle attacker) can overwrite arbitrary files in the rsync client target directory and subdirectories (for example, overwrite the .ssh/authorized_keys file).

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Improper argument validation in rsync client request/response leads to arbitrary file overwrite when an attacker controls the remote server or by means of man-in-the-middle attack.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[rsync](https://github.com/WayneD/rsync) is a utility for efficiently transferring and synchronizing files between a computer and a storage drive and across networked computers by comparing the modification times and sizes of files.

When performing a copy from a remote server with `rsync` an attacker that controls the rsync server or that performs a man-in-the-middle attack, can add arbitrary files to be copied under the target directory (or any of its subdirectories).

For example, the `rsync -aiv host1:dir1 ~` command copies from `host1:dir1` to the local home directory (`~`). In this scenario the attacker would be able to overwrite the `.ssh/authorized_keys` file located in the home directory and then compromise the system running the `rsync` client.
The attacker is limited to the target directory of `rsync`, therefore a restricted and dedicated target directory will decrease the vulnerability's impact dramatically.
high_profile_info.Resolution:
##### Deployment mitigations

Perform the rsync copy into a dedicated directory instead of directory used for other files like the home directory.

Replace the following insecure example:
```
rsync -aiv host1:dir1 ~
```
By a safer one using a dedicated directory:
```
rsync -aiv host1:dir1 ~/host1-files
```
This example will use the `host1-files` directory instead of the home directory for the rsync copy.
After running `rsync`, the needed files can be moved (using `mv`) to their original target location.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The impact of exploiting the issue depends on the context of surrounding software. A severe impact such as RCE is not guaranteed.
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Leads to Arbitrary File Overwrite in the target directory. If the target directory contains important files, the vulnerability could lead to code execution.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploiting the issue requires the user to interact with the vulnerable software
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Requires the user to perform a `rsync` copy to a unsafe location

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Since rsync does not use encryption, a local network attacker may perform this attack using the man-in-the-middle technique

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC

ExtendedReferences.Title: OSS Security discussion about the issue

data.summary: git_connect_git in connect.c in Git before 2.30.1 allows a repository path to contain a newline character, which may result in unexpected cross-protocol requests, as demonstrated by the git://localhost:1234/%0d%0a%0d%0aGET%20/%20HTTP/1.1 substring.

more_details.description: git_connect_git in connect.c in Git before 2.30.1 allows a repository path to contain a newline character, which may result in unexpected cross-protocol requests, as demonstrated by the git://localhost:1234/%0d%0a%0d%0aGET%20/%20HTTP/1.1 substring.

data.summary: A vulnerability in input validation exists in curl <8.0 during communication using the TELNET protocol may allow an attacker to pass on maliciously crafted user name and "telnet options" during server negotiation. The lack of proper input scrubbing allows an attacker to send content or perform option negotiation without the application's intent. This vulnerability could be exploited if an application allows user input, thereby enabling attackers to execute arbitrary code on the system.

more_details.description: A vulnerability in input validation exists in curl <8.0 during communication using the TELNET protocol may allow an attacker to pass on maliciously crafted user name and "telnet options" during server negotiation. The lack of proper input scrubbing allows an attacker to send content or perform option negotiation without the application's intent. This vulnerability could be exploited if an application allows user input, thereby enabling attackers to execute arbitrary code on the system.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Improper command sanitization in curl can lead to content passing through specific options when telnet is enabled.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Curl](https://curl.se/) is a command-line tool for transferring data from or to a server, using various protocols like HTTP, FTP, SMTP, and more.
An issue has been discovered in curl that allows an attacker to inject arbitrary Telnet commands via the Telnet option flag (`--telnet-option` in the command line or `CURLOPT_TELNETOPTIONS` in the code) when using three (rarely used) options - `TTYPE`, `XDISPLOC` and `NEW_ENV`.
 
The original report also mentions arbitrary code execution that finally turns out to be impossible. At most, it can only impact applications relying specifically on Telnet options but not the data sent to the server.

Example vulnerable invocation -
`curl --telnet-option NEW_ENV=a,b$(echo -ne "\xff\xf0INJECTED") telnet://server`
The above example will inject the "INJECTED" command

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: As described in the report, the impact and the very rare use of the affected Telnet options make the CVSS inconsistent.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
Attackers must find an input that allows them to insert arbitrary values for the following Telnet options -
* `TTYPE`
* `XDISPLOC`
* `NEW_ENV`
Which is an extremely unlikely scenario

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Telnet is an inherently insecure protocol and an attacker is much more likely to be able to sniff or inject Telnet data using a Man-in-the-middle attack regardless of this vulnerability, which has very rare prerequisites

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: An attacker can inject arbitrary Telnet commands instead of the intended Telnet options

data.summary: A vulnerability classified as critical has been found in Linux Kernel. Affected is the function btf_dump_name_dups of the file tools/lib/bpf/btf_dump.c of the component libbpf. The manipulation leads to use after free. It is recommended to apply a patch to fix this issue. The identifier of this vulnerability is VDB-211032.

more_details.description: A vulnerability classified as critical has been found in Linux Kernel. Affected is the function btf_dump_name_dups of the file tools/lib/bpf/btf_dump.c of the component libbpf. The manipulation leads to use after free. It is recommended to apply a patch to fix this issue. The identifier of this vulnerability is VDB-211032.

data.summary: CPAN.pm before 2.35 does not verify TLS certificates when downloading distributions over HTTPS.

more_details.description: CPAN.pm before 2.35 does not verify TLS certificates when downloading distributions over HTTPS.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Missing TLS check in CPAN.pm allows man-in-the-middle attacks when downloading packages and may lead to code execution.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[CPAN.pm](https://metacpan.org/pod/CPAN) is a Perl module and command-line tool that provides an automated and standardized way to download, install, and manage Perl modules and their dependencies from the Comprehensive Perl Archive Network (CPAN).
[HTTP::Tiny](https://metacpan.org/pod/HTTP::Tiny) is an HTTP client in Perl and a standalone CPAN module. By default, it does not verify TLS certificates. To enable it, the `verify_SSL=>1` flag should be specified when initializing the `HTTP::Tiny` object. The problem identified in `HTTP::Tiny` has been assigned the CVE identifier `CVE-2023-31486` and serves as the underlying cause for the problem in `CPAN.pm`.

`CPAN.pm` downloads and executes code through the `install` command followed by the package name.
Although `CPAN.pm` downloads from `https://cpan.org`, it does not enable TLS certificate verification while using `HTTP::Tiny`, which could potentially allow an attacker to perform a man-in-the-middle attack by injecting malicious data that could be executed by CPAN.pm.

Example of a vulnerable code:
```
use CPAN;
install DateTime
```

Example of a vulnerable command-line:
```
cpan install DateTime
```

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Exploitation only requires an attacker to perform a man-in-the-middle attack (which is extensively documented) and provide the victim with a malicious package instead of the legitimate one.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: This issue may lead to code execution.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has a detailed technical explanation published, that can aid in exploit development
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: A technical write-up exists.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The attacker should be in the network to perform a man-in-the-middle attack, and then provide a malicious package when the victim installs a new CPAN.pm package.

data.summary: Git is a revision control system. Prior to versions 2.30.9, 2.31.8, 2.32.7, 2.33.8, 2.34.8, 2.35.8, 2.36.6, 2.37.7, 2.38.5, 2.39.3, and 2.40.1, by feeding specially crafted input to `git apply --reject`, a path outside the working tree can be overwritten with partially controlled contents (corresponding to the rejected hunk(s) from the given patch). A fix is available in versions 2.30.9, 2.31.8, 2.32.7, 2.33.8, 2.34.8, 2.35.8, 2.36.6, 2.37.7, 2.38.5, 2.39.3, and 2.40.1. As a workaround, avoid using `git apply` with `--reject` when applying patches from an untrusted source. Use `git apply --stat` to inspect a patch before applying; avoid applying one that create a conflict where a link corresponding to the `*.rej` file exists.

more_details.description: Git is a revision control system. Prior to versions 2.30.9, 2.31.8, 2.32.7, 2.33.8, 2.34.8, 2.35.8, 2.36.6, 2.37.7, 2.38.5, 2.39.3, and 2.40.1, by feeding specially crafted input to `git apply --reject`, a path outside the working tree can be overwritten with partially controlled contents (corresponding to the rejected hunk(s) from the given patch). A fix is available in versions 2.30.9, 2.31.8, 2.32.7, 2.33.8, 2.34.8, 2.35.8, 2.36.6, 2.37.7, 2.38.5, 2.39.3, and 2.40.1. As a workaround, avoid using `git apply` with `--reject` when applying patches from an untrusted source. Use `git apply --stat` to inspect a patch before applying; avoid applying one that create a conflict where a link corresponding to the `*.rej` file exists.

data.summary: In Python (aka CPython) up to 3.10.8, the mailcap module does not add escape characters into commands discovered in the system mailcap file. This may allow attackers to inject shell commands into applications that call mailcap.findmatch with untrusted input (if they lack validation of user-provided filenames or arguments). The fix is also back-ported to 3.7, 3.8, 3.9

more_details.description: In Python (aka CPython) up to 3.10.8, the mailcap module does not add escape characters into commands discovered in the system mailcap file. This may allow attackers to inject shell commands into applications that call mailcap.findmatch with untrusted input (if they lack validation of user-provided filenames or arguments). The fix is also back-ported to 3.7, 3.8, 3.9

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Insufficient input validation in findmatch() function of the Python mailcap module, allows attackers to perform remote code execution.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
The [mailcap](https://docs.python.org/2/library/mailcap.html) library is part of the Python Standard Library ([CPython](https://github.com/python/cpython)). The library is responsible for configuring how MIME-aware applications such as mail readers and Web browsers handle files with different [MIME types](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Media_type). 

The library implementation has a bug in the `mailcap.findmatch()` function, where the `filename` argument is not being sanitized and added as-is to the command line string that is returned from the function. This command line is then usually executed by the application that uses the library to invoke the program that handles the MIME type. If the library is used as a command line tool, this invocation happens automatically by the function `test()` that executes the MIME program automatically to test its return value.

The vulnerability can be exploited if the `findmatch()` function is used and no external user input validation is implemented. In that state, the vulnerability may be exploited by injecting shell commands into the `filename` argument, which will likely be executed later. 

Example of injecting shell command into `filename` argument when using the library in Python code: 
```
commandline, MIMEtype = mailcap.findmatch(
    d, "text/*", filename="'filename; echo HACKED'"
)
os.system(commandline)
```

Example of automatic execution of the injected shell when using the library as a standalone tool:
```
python3 -m mailcap text/html 'filename; echo HACKED'
```

The original issue was discovered in 2015, and although a patch was suggested by a maintainer this year it remained an issue until in 2022 the CVE was published since it was discovered that the `mailcap.findmatch()` function is still exploitable. As a result, the CPython team updated the `mailcap.findmatch()` function to disable ASCII characters other than alphanumerics and `@+=:,./-_` from being injected into the returned command line".
high_profile_info.Resolution:
##### Development mitigations

If possible, avoid using the library for MIME type handling.
If not, sanitize the data that is passed to `filename` parameter of `findmatch()` before calling the function with user-supplied input. It is recommended to sanitize any non-alphanumeric characters to avoid command injections to this argument.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Malicious commands can be easily injected into the `filename` parameter when user-controlled data is passed to it.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are either extremely common or nonexistent (always exploitable)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Applications that use this library, like Email readers or web-content viewers, are likely to process user-controlled data with the vulnerable function, for detecting the program that should handle any kind of MIME type content.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Exploiting this vulnerability can lead to remote code execution when the `filename` argument of `mailcap.findmatch()` is controlled by a user.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
For exploiting this vulnerability, a user should be able to supply input to the `filename` argument of `mailcap.findmatch()`.
Then, the output returned from `findmatch()` function has to be executed as a command line by the application (for example with `os.system()`)
In case the `mailcap` library is used as a command line tool it executes the output automatically.

data.summary: In Python (aka CPython) up to 3.10.8, the mailcap module does not add escape characters into commands discovered in the system mailcap file. This may allow attackers to inject shell commands into applications that call mailcap.findmatch with untrusted input (if they lack validation of user-provided filenames or arguments). The fix is also back-ported to 3.7, 3.8, 3.9

This may allow attackers to inject shell commands into applications that call mailcap.findmatch with untrusted input (if they lack validation of user-provided filenames or arguments). The fix is also back-ported to 3.7, 3.8, 3.9


The original issue was discovered in 2015, and although a patch was suggested by a maintainer this year it remained an issue until in 2022 the CVE was published since it was discovered that the `mailcap.findmatch()` function is still exploitable. As a result, the CPython team updated the `mailcap.findmatch()` function to disable ASCII characters other than alphanumerics and `@+=:,./-_` from being injected into the returned command line".
high_profile_info.Resolution:
##### Development mitigations

If possible, avoid using the library for MIME type handling.
If not, sanitize the data that is passed to `filename` parameter of `findmatch()` before calling the function with user-supplied input. It is recommended to sanitize any non-alphanumeric characters to avoid command injections to this argument.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Malicious commands can be easily injected into the `filename` parameter when user-controlled data is passed to it.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are either extremely common or nonexistent (always exploitable)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Applications that use this library, like Email readers or web-content viewers, are likely to process user-controlled data with the vulnerable function, for detecting the program that should handle any kind of MIME type content.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Exploiting this vulnerability can lead to remote code execution when the `filename` argument of `mailcap.findmatch()` is controlled by a user.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
For exploiting this vulnerability, a user should be able to supply input to the `filename` argument of `mailcap.findmatch()`.
Then, the output returned from `findmatch()` function has to be executed as a command line by the application (for example with `os.system()`)
In case the `mailcap` library is used as a command line tool it executes the output automatically.

data.summary: CPAN.pm before 2.35 does not verify TLS certificates when downloading distributions over HTTPS.

more_details.description: CPAN.pm before 2.35 does not verify TLS certificates when downloading distributions over HTTPS.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Missing TLS check in CPAN.pm allows man-in-the-middle attacks when downloading packages and may lead to code execution.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[CPAN.pm](https://metacpan.org/pod/CPAN) is a Perl module and command-line tool that provides an automated and standardized way to download, install, and manage Perl modules and their dependencies from the Comprehensive Perl Archive Network (CPAN).
[HTTP::Tiny](https://metacpan.org/pod/HTTP::Tiny) is an HTTP client in Perl and a standalone CPAN module. By default, it does not verify TLS certificates. To enable it, the `verify_SSL=>1` flag should be specified when initializing the `HTTP::Tiny` object. The problem identified in `HTTP::Tiny` has been assigned the CVE identifier `CVE-2023-31486` and serves as the underlying cause for the problem in `CPAN.pm`.

`CPAN.pm` downloads and executes code through the `install` command followed by the package name.
Although `CPAN.pm` downloads from `https://cpan.org`, it does not enable TLS certificate verification while using `HTTP::Tiny`, which could potentially allow an attacker to perform a man-in-the-middle attack by injecting malicious data that could be executed by CPAN.pm.

Example of a vulnerable code:
```
use CPAN;
install DateTime
```

Example of a vulnerable command-line:
```
cpan install DateTime
```

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Exploitation only requires an attacker to perform a man-in-the-middle attack (which is extensively documented) and provide the victim with a malicious package instead of the legitimate one.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: This issue may lead to code execution.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has a detailed technical explanation published, that can aid in exploit development
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: A technical write-up exists.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The attacker should be in the network to perform a man-in-the-middle attack, and then provide a malicious package when the victim installs a new CPAN.pm package.

data.summary: An issue in the urllib.parse component of Python before v3.11 allows attackers to bypass blocklisting methods by supplying a URL that starts with blank characters.

more_details.description: An issue in the urllib.parse component of Python before v3.11 allows attackers to bypass blocklisting methods by supplying a URL that starts with blank characters.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Improper URL parsing in Python can lead to filter bypass when comparing the URL's scheme.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
`urllib.parse` is a widely used module for parsing URLs in Python. One of its core functions, `urlparse`, incorrectly parses URL that start with blank characters, causing any blacklisting methods based on the parsed scheme to fail, as shown in the following example where the `input_scheme` is blank -
```py
from urllib.parse import urlparse

input_scheme = urlparse(" file://127.0.0.1/etc/passwd").scheme
print(input_scheme)
```
The `input_scheme` value is ` ` instead of the expected value of `file`.
high_profile_info.Resolution:
##### Development mitigations

Adding a call to `lstrip` before calling `urlparse` removes the leading blanks, which mitigates the vulnerability - 
```
url = url.lstrip()
...
urlparse(url)
```

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The impact of exploiting the issue depends on the context of surrounding software. A severe impact such as RCE is not guaranteed.
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The security impact of this issue depends on what is done with the parsed scheme of the URL. If the parsed scheme is compared to a blacklist in order to deny specific operations, there may be a security impact when exploiting this issue.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
An attacker must find a remote input that propagates to the `urlparse()` function in which the `scheme` member is accessed.
For example - 
```python
input_scheme = urlparse(attacker_url).scheme
```

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The vulnerability can easily be exploited by adding blank characters at the beginning of the parsed URL

data.summary: A buffer overflow was discovered in the GNU C Library's dynamic loader ld.so while processing the GLIBC_TUNABLES environment variable. This issue could allow a local attacker to use maliciously crafted GLIBC_TUNABLES environment variables when launching binaries with SUID permission to execute code with elevated privileges.

more_details.description: A buffer overflow was discovered in the GNU C Library's dynamic loader ld.so while processing the GLIBC_TUNABLES environment variable. This issue could allow a local attacker to use maliciously crafted GLIBC_TUNABLES environment variables when launching binaries with SUID permission to execute code with elevated privileges.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: A buffer overflow in glibc may lead to local privilege escalation when parsing a malicious environment variable.
high_profile_info.FullDescription: At the beginning of its execution, ld.so is responsible for loading GLIBC_TUNABLES environment variables. A notable issue emerges when a GLIBC_TUNABLES variable adopts the format "tunable1=tunable2=AAA", and both "tunable1" and "tunable2" are SXID_IGNORE tunables. This particular scenario can lead to a buffer overflow in the copied GLIBC_TUNABLES variable. Utilizing this buffer overflow vulnerability, an attacker gains the ability to overwrite the pointer that directs the dynamic loader to its library search path. This pointer is critical in determining where the dynamic loader locates essential libraries. By manipulating this pointer, the attacker redirects the dynamic loader to load a malicious libc.so library situated in a location controlled by them. This malicious library may execute harmful code, ultimately facilitating an escalation of privileges.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue can only be exploited by an attacker that can execute code on the vulnerable machine (excluding exceedingly rare circumstances)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: This vulnerability requires local access to exploit.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: This vulnerability has several published exploits with an extensive technical write-up. The Proof-of-concept has been demonstrated to lead to full root privileges on major Linux distributions: Ubuntu, Fedora, and Debian.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has multiple mentions in general media
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The vulnerability received extensive media coverage and was nicknamed `Looney Tunables`.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are either extremely common or nonexistent (always exploitable)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The requirements to trigger the vulnerability are highly likely on default Linux machines.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
The vulnerability requires the following to be exploited:
1. `GLIBC_TUNABLES` environment variable being enabled, which is enabled by default.
2. The `ld.so` binary (the dynamic loader) must have SUID permissions, which is common on Linux.

data.summary: Use After Free in GitHub repository vim/vim prior to 9.0.1858.

more_details.description: Use After Free in GitHub repository vim/vim prior to 9.0.1858.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: (Non-Issue) Use-after-free in vim leads to denial of service and potentially code execution when running crafted vim commands.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Vim](https://www.vim.org/) is a free, open-source, screen-based text editor program for Unix.
Vim has an `Ex mode` that allows entering Ex commands and is designed for Batch processing.

The Ex, or colon, commands are based on the line editor named ex. In general, they operate on the document as a whole, or large portions of it (although there are commands to perform essentially every editing task).

It was discovered that when sourcing a file using Vim `Ex mode`, a use-after-free may occur, which leads to a denial of service.

`vim` can be run with one or more flags. These flags include, but are not limited to:

* `-e`: With the `-e` flag, the user enters Ex mode. The Ex mode is similar to the command line mode as it also allows you to enter Ex commands.
* `-s`: With the `-s` flag, the user can silence the ex mode, to support batch commands.
* `-S`: With the `-S` flag, the user sources the file after loading it.

The issue requires the victim to run an attacker's specially crafted file in `Ex mode` and source it as well.
An example of a vulnerable command line:
`vim -e -s -S {malicious_file}`

Opening files with vim in this specific mode is highly unlikely.

This vulnerability has no security impact at all since if an attacker can run arbitrary vim commands, then the attacker can also execute arbitrary shell commands using the exclamation mark, and does not need this vulnerability to achieve code execution. For example running the vim command `!ls` will execute the shell command `ls`.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: To exploit this issue Vim must be run in `Ex mode` and also source the malicious text file.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: An exploit has been published along with the original report.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: This vulnerability has no security impact since if an attacker can run arbitrary vim commands, then the attacker can also execute arbitrary shell commands using the exclamation mark, and does not need this vulnerability to achieve code execution.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploiting the issue requires the user to interact with the vulnerable software
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The victim must open the attacker's crafted text file in Vim.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The CVSS does not reflect the contextual prerequisites required to exploit the vulnerability.

data.summary: A vulnerability was found in libcap. This issue occurs in the _libcap_strdup() function and can lead to an integer overflow if the input string is close to 4GiB.

more_details.description: A vulnerability was found in libcap. This issue occurs in the _libcap_strdup() function and can lead to an integer overflow if the input string is close to 4GiB.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: An integer overflow in libcap may lead to denial of service when parsing user input.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
`libcap` is a library for getting and setting POSIX. 1e Linux capabilities. With libcap, you can assign specific capabilities to a process or binary, allowing it to perform privileged operations without requiring full root access.

The library implementation has a bug in the ` _libcap_strdup()` function. The code that checks for integer overflow assumes that the computed value of `len` will always be less than the max value of a 32-bit unsigned int. This bad logic assumption leads to integer overflow and heap overwrite when supplying large input (close to 4 GB).

An attacker must be able to find an input that propagates into the vulnerable function in order to exploit this vulnerability. In addition, this vulnerability is only applicable on a 64-bit kernel in 32-bit compatibility mode (a feature that allows 32-bit applications to run on a 64-bit Linux system). 

The official fix solves this issue by checking for integer overflow earlier and comparing max int against the old value of `len` (`old`) and only after that computing its new value. In this way, the integer overflow check is effective in preventing integer overflow attacks.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: This vulnerability is only applicable on a 64-bit kernel in 32-bit compatibility mode. Moreover, in order to exploit this vulnerability, an attacker must be able to supply a very large string (close to 4 GB) that will propagate to the vulnerable function.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The CVSS does not reflect the contextual prerequisites required to exploit the vulnerability.

data.summary: Heap-based Buffer Overflow in GitHub repository vim/vim prior to 9.0.1848.

more_details.description: Heap-based Buffer Overflow in GitHub repository vim/vim prior to 9.0.1848.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: (Non-Issue) Buffer overflow in vim leads to denial of service and potentially code execution when running crafted vim commands.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Vim](https://www.vim.org/) is a free, open-source, screen-based text editor program for Unix.
Vim has an `Ex mode` that allows entering Ex commands and is designed for Batch processing.

The Ex, or colon, commands are based on the line editor named ex. In general, they operate on the document as a whole, or large portions of it (although there are commands to perform essentially every editing task).

It was discovered that when sourcing a file using Vim `Ex mode`, a heap overflow may occur, which leads to a denial of service.

`vim` can be run with one or more flags. These flags include, but are not limited to:

* `-e`: With the `-e` flag, the user enters Ex mode. The Ex mode is similar to the command line mode as it also allows you to enter Ex commands.
* `-s`: With the `-s` flag, the user can silence the ex mode, to support batch commands.
* `-S`: With the `-S` flag, the user sources the file after loading it.

The issue requires the victim to run an attacker's specially crafted file in `Ex mode` and source it as well.
An example of a vulnerable command line:
`vim -e -s -S {malicious_file}`

Opening files with vim in this specific mode is highly unlikely.

This vulnerability has no security impact at all since if an attacker can run arbitrary vim commands, then the attacker can also execute arbitrary shell commands using the exclamation mark, and does not need this vulnerability to achieve code execution. For example running the vim command `!ls` will execute the shell command `ls`.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: To exploit this issue Vim must be run in `Ex mode` and also source the malicious text file.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploiting the issue requires the user to interact with the vulnerable software
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The victim must open the attacker's crafted text file in Vim.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The CVSS does not reflect the contextual prerequisites required to exploit the vulnerability.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: This vulnerability has no security impact since if an attacker can run arbitrary vim commands, then the attacker can also execute arbitrary shell commands using the exclamation mark, and does not need this vulnerability to achieve code execution.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: An exploit has been published along with the original report.

data.summary: CPAN.pm before 2.35 does not verify TLS certificates when downloading distributions over HTTPS.

more_details.description: CPAN.pm before 2.35 does not verify TLS certificates when downloading distributions over HTTPS.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Missing TLS check in CPAN.pm allows man-in-the-middle attacks when downloading packages and may lead to code execution.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[CPAN.pm](https://metacpan.org/pod/CPAN) is a Perl module and command-line tool that provides an automated and standardized way to download, install, and manage Perl modules and their dependencies from the Comprehensive Perl Archive Network (CPAN).
[HTTP::Tiny](https://metacpan.org/pod/HTTP::Tiny) is an HTTP client in Perl and a standalone CPAN module. By default, it does not verify TLS certificates. To enable it, the `verify_SSL=>1` flag should be specified when initializing the `HTTP::Tiny` object. The problem identified in `HTTP::Tiny` has been assigned the CVE identifier `CVE-2023-31486` and serves as the underlying cause for the problem in `CPAN.pm`.

`CPAN.pm` downloads and executes code through the `install` command followed by the package name.
Although `CPAN.pm` downloads from `https://cpan.org`, it does not enable TLS certificate verification while using `HTTP::Tiny`, which could potentially allow an attacker to perform a man-in-the-middle attack by injecting malicious data that could be executed by CPAN.pm.

Example of a vulnerable code:
```
use CPAN;
install DateTime
```

Example of a vulnerable command-line:
```
cpan install DateTime
```

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Exploitation only requires an attacker to perform a man-in-the-middle attack (which is extensively documented) and provide the victim with a malicious package instead of the legitimate one.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: This issue may lead to code execution.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has a detailed technical explanation published, that can aid in exploit development
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: A technical write-up exists.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The attacker should be in the network to perform a man-in-the-middle attack, and then provide a malicious package when the victim installs a new CPAN.pm package.

data.summary: A flaw was found in Python, specifically within the urllib.parse module. This module helps break Uniform Resource Locator (URL) strings into components. The issue involves how the urlparse method does not sanitize input and allows characters like '\r' and '\n' in the URL path. This flaw allows an attacker to input a crafted URL, leading to injection attacks. This flaw affects Python versions prior to 3.10.0b1, 3.9.5, 3.8.11, 3.7.11 and 3.6.14.

more_details.description: A flaw was found in Python, specifically within the urllib.parse module. This module helps break Uniform Resource Locator (URL) strings into components. The issue involves how the urlparse method does not sanitize input and allows characters like '\r' and '\n' in the URL path. This flaw allows an attacker to input a crafted URL, leading to injection attacks. This flaw affects Python versions prior to 3.10.0b1, 3.9.5, 3.8.11, 3.7.11 and 3.6.14.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Improper URL parsing in Python can lead to filter bypass when comparing the URL's scheme.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
The `urllib` package in Python is a built-in module that provides a set of functions for working with URLs (Uniform Resource Locators). It offers capabilities for making HTTP requests, handling URL encodings, parsing URLs, and other common tasks related to web interactions.

The `urllib.parse` module, part of the `urllib` package in Python, provides functions for parsing and manipulating URLs. It offers utilities for URL encoding and decoding, splitting URLs into components, constructing URLs from components, and other URL-related operations.

The `urlparse()` or `urlsplit()` functions have been found to have a flaw during URL processing. This vulnerability allows an attacker to pass an invalid URL that contains newlines and tabs without undergoing proper sanitation.
This violates the URL Specification, which mandates the removal of all newlines and tabs from a URL prior to processing.

The issue could cause any blacklisting methods based on the parsed URL to fail.

An example where the URL path is not parsed correctly -
```py
from urllib.parse import urlsplit

splitresult = urlsplit("fi\nle://127.0.0.1/etc/passwd")
print(splitresult)
```

The result would be:
```
SplitResult(scheme='', netloc='', path="fi\nle://127.0.0.1/etc/passwd", query='', fragment='')
```

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The impact of exploiting the issue depends on the context of surrounding software. A severe impact such as RCE is not guaranteed.
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The security impact of this issue depends on what is done with the parsed URL. If the parsed URL is compared to a blacklist in order to deny specific operations, there may be a security impact when exploiting this issue.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: It is common to use this library for parsing URLs that are provided by remote users.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: An attacker must find a remote input that propagates to the `urlparse()` function.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The vulnerability can be easily triggered by adding newline or tab characters to the parsed URL.

data.summary: A flaw was found in python. In algorithms with quadratic time complexity using non-binary bases, when using int("text"), a system could take 50ms to parse an int string with 100,000 digits and 5s for 1,000,000 digits (float, decimal, int.from_bytes(), and int() for binary bases 2, 4, 8, 16, and 32 are not affected). The highest threat from this vulnerability is to system availability.

more_details.description: A flaw was found in python. In algorithms with quadratic time complexity using non-binary bases, when using int("text"), a system could take 50ms to parse an int string with 100,000 digits and 5s for 1,000,000 digits (float, decimal, int.from_bytes(), and int() for binary bases 2, 4, 8, 16, and 32 are not affected). The highest threat from this vulnerability is to system availability.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Inefficient algorithm in Python integer parsing leads to denial of service when converting user-supplied integer strings.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
Python contains the built-in `int()` and `str()` functions which enable integer conversion to and from strings. To be able to convert a big number, Python uses an algorithm with a quadratic complexity.

A long string could cause a very long time response and then makes the system unavailable for a long time.
For example -
```py
>>> n = 10**(10**7) 
>>> s = str(n)  # expect instant ValueError, but takes many minutes
```

Or alternatively -
```py
>>> s = "1'+'0'*1000000
>>> i = int(s)  # expect instant ValueError, but takes many minutes
```

Currently, no fixed versions of Python are available since this issue is still in discussion

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The attacker must continuously repeat the attack to gain a persistent DoS

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
Example making the system unavailable for many minutes -
```py
>>> n = 10**(10**7)  # takes a few seconds to run 
>>> s = str(n)  # expect instant ValueError, but takes many minutes
```

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The attacker must find an input that propagates into the `int()` or `str()` methods,  without any limit on the given integer/string

data.summary: A path traversal vulnerability exists in curl <8.0.0 SFTP implementation causes the tilde (~) character to be wrongly replaced when used as a prefix in the first path element, in addition to its intended use as the first element to indicate a path relative to the user's home directory. Attackers can exploit this flaw to bypass filtering or execute arbitrary code by crafting a path like /~2/foo while accessing a server with a specific user.

more_details.description: A path traversal vulnerability exists in curl <8.0.0 SFTP implementation causes the tilde (~) character to be wrongly replaced when used as a prefix in the first path element, in addition to its intended use as the first element to indicate a path relative to the user's home directory. Attackers can exploit this flaw to bypass filtering or execute arbitrary code by crafting a path like /~2/foo while accessing a server with a specific user.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Incorrect path limitation in curl's SFTP implementation can lead to path traversal when processing a path containing the `~` character.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Curl](https://curl.se/) is a command-line tool for transferring data from or to a server, using various protocols like HTTP, FTP, SMTP, and more.
curl's [SFTP implementation](https://everything.curl.dev/usingcurl/scpsftp) includes a special feature for URL paths, whereby using a tilde (`~`) in the first element of a path indicates that it should be relative to the user's home directory. As a result, the Curl_getworkingpath function in libcurl replaces `/~/` with the user's home path.

However, using `/~../` can bypass the path traversal logic in `Curl_getworkingpath` due to the tilde character. This resolves to `/home/user/../` and can allow attackers to access remote system path locations that were not intended to be accessible.

To fully exploit this issue and gain access to other users' home directories and retrieve files, attackers must compromise a highly privileged account.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: This issue is very limited as the tilde character should be in the first path element and the user can only access files he has been given permission to access.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The impact of exploiting the issue depends on the context of surrounding software. A severe impact such as RCE is not guaranteed.
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The attacker can only access files for which the compromised user account used to establish the SFTP transfer has been granted permission.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The path traversal possibilities from this issue are very limited.

data.summary: An issue was discovered in Python before 3.11.1. An unnecessary quadratic algorithm exists in one path when processing some inputs to the IDNA (RFC 3490) decoder, such that a crafted, unreasonably long name being presented to the decoder could lead to a CPU denial of service. Hostnames are often supplied by remote servers that could be controlled by a malicious actor; in such a scenario, they could trigger excessive CPU consumption on the client attempting to make use of an attacker-supplied supposed hostname. For example, the attack payload could be placed in the Location header of an HTTP response with status code 302. A fix is planned in 3.11.1, 3.10.9, 3.9.16, 3.8.16, and 3.7.16.

more_details.description: An issue was discovered in Python before 3.11.1. An unnecessary quadratic algorithm exists in one path when processing some inputs to the IDNA (RFC 3490) decoder, such that a crafted, unreasonably long name being presented to the decoder could lead to a CPU denial of service. Hostnames are often supplied by remote servers that could be controlled by a malicious actor; in such a scenario, they could trigger excessive CPU consumption on the client attempting to make use of an attacker-supplied supposed hostname. For example, the attack payload could be placed in the Location header of an HTTP response with status code 302. A fix is planned in 3.11.1, 3.10.9, 3.9.16, 3.8.16, and 3.7.16.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Inefficient decoding algorithm in Python's idna module can lead to excessive CPU consumption when decoding a crafted domain name.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Python](https://www.python.org/) is a high-level, interpreted programming language known for its simplicity, readability, and versatility.
The Python standard library is a collection of modules and packages that are part of the Python distribution by default and provides a wide range of functionality for common tasks, such as working with data structures, file I/O, networking, and more.
IDNA (Internationalized Domain Names in Applications) encoding and decoding is part of Python's standard library, specifically the `encodings.idna` module, which provides functions to convert domain names between their ASCII and Unicode forms according to the IDNA specification.

When processing certain domain names as input, the `idna.decode()` function could cause excessive CPU consumption and result in a DoS. Since hostnames are often supplied by remote servers that could be controlled by an attacker, the vulnerability could be exploited by triggering the CPU consumption on a client attempting to process a crafted, unreasonably long name.

Note that according to IDNA specifications, the IDNA label names cannot be more than 63 ASCII characters. However, Python's `idna` module does not enforce this restriction.

Vulnerable code snippet #1 -
```python
import idna
idna.decode(external_input)
```

Vulnerable code snippet #2 -
```python
external_input_bytes.decode('idna')
```

Note that some Python 3rd-party libraries, such as [requests](https://pypi.org/project/requests/) may be vulnerable to this issue remotely. For example, the `urllib.request.HTTPRedirectHandler` class passes the `Location` response header to the idna module directly, when parsing an HTTP 302 redirect response.
high_profile_info.Resolution:
##### Development mitigations

As an IDNA label must not be longer than 63 characters, a simple check before the call to the `decode('idna')` function would mitigate this vulnerability -
```python
if len(idna_label) <= 63:
    decoded_name = idna_label.decode('idna')
else:
    # FAIL
```

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Public exploit demonstrates DoS

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The attacker must find remote input that propagates to the idna.decode() API function

data.summary: ** DISPUTED ** Python 3.x through 3.10 has an open redirection vulnerability in lib/http/server.py due to no protection against multiple (/) at the beginning of URI path which may leads to information disclosure. NOTE: this is disputed by a third party because the http.server.html documentation page states "Warning: http.server is not recommended for production. It only implements basic security checks."

more_details.description: ** DISPUTED ** Python 3.x through 3.10 has an open redirection vulnerability in lib/http/server.py due to no protection against multiple (/) at the beginning of URI path which may leads to information disclosure. NOTE: this is disputed by a third party because the http.server.html documentation page states "Warning: http.server is not recommended for production. It only implements basic security checks."

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Improper URI path validation in Python 3.x HTTP server leads to open redirect when surfing to a crafted URL.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Python](https://www.python.org/) is a popular high-level, interpreted, general-purpose programming language.

`HTTPServer` class, is a `socketserver.TCPServer` subclass. It creates and listens at the HTTP socket, dispatching the requests to a handler. A flaw in the [`URI path`](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uniform_Resource_Identifier#Syntax) validation, causing [open redirection](https://brightsec.com/blog/open-redirect-vulnerabilities/), can lead to data leakage.

Example:
```
http://127.0.0.1:8000//attacker.com/..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f../%0a%0d/../.ssh
```
The multiple `/` is interpreted as a domain name. The last one will be processed as the good one. Here, `attacker.com` is considered as the domain and so it will set the `Location` parameter of the response to this value. Thus, it will redirect the client to the `attacker.com` domain. 

This CVE was disputed, as the `http.server` module is not made for production but only for test purposes, as mentioned in the documentation.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has been disputed by the vendor
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: It is a disputed CVE as the `http.server` module is not made for production but only for test as it is written in the documentation.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
Example of a crafted URL that will lead the victim to "attacker.com" when surfed to (instead of the expected "pythonserver.com")
```
http://pythonserver.com:8000//attacker.com/..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f..%2f../%0a%0d/../.ssh
```
The multiple `/` is interpreted as a domain name. The last one will be processed as the good one. Here, `attacker.com` is considered as the domain and so it will set the `Location` parameter of the response to this value. Thus, it will read the `.ssh` file content and send it to the `attacker.com` domain.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has a detailed technical explanation published, that can aid in exploit development
The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Open redirection

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploiting the issue requires the user to interact with the vulnerable software
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: A user must surf to the attacker's crafted URL

The Python standard library is a collection of modules and packages that are part of the Python distribution by default and provides a wide range of functionality for common tasks, such as working with data structures, file I/O, networking, and more.
IDNA (Internationalized Domain Names in Applications) encoding and decoding is part of Python's standard library, specifically the `encodings.idna` module, which provides functions to convert domain names between their ASCII and Unicode forms according to the IDNA specification.

When processing certain domain names as input, the `idna.decode()` function could cause excessive CPU consumption and result in a DoS. Since hostnames are often supplied by remote servers that could be controlled by an attacker, the vulnerability could be exploited by triggering the CPU consumption on a client attempting to process a crafted, unreasonably long name.

Note that according to IDNA specifications, the IDNA label names cannot be more than 63 ASCII characters. However, Python's `idna` module does not enforce this restriction.

Vulnerable code snippet #1 -
```python
import idna
idna.decode(external_input)
```

Vulnerable code snippet #2 -
```python
external_input_bytes.decode('idna')
```

Note that some Python 3rd-party libraries, such as [requests](https://pypi.org/project/requests/) may be vulnerable to this issue remotely. For example, the `urllib.request.HTTPRedirectHandler` class passes the `Location` response header to the idna module directly, when parsing an HTTP 302 redirect response.
high_profile_info.Resolution:
##### Development mitigations

As an IDNA label must not be longer than 63 characters, a simple check before the call to the `decode('idna')` function would mitigate this vulnerability -
```python
if len(idna_label) <= 63:
    decoded_name = idna_label.decode('idna')
else:
    # FAIL
```

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Public exploit demonstrates DoS

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The attacker must find remote input that propagates to the idna.decode() API function

data.summary: Git is a revision control system. Prior to versions 2.30.9, 2.31.8, 2.32.7, 2.33.8, 2.34.8, 2.35.8, 2.36.6, 2.37.7, 2.38.5, 2.39.3, and 2.40.1, by feeding specially crafted input to `git apply --reject`, a path outside the working tree can be overwritten with partially controlled contents (corresponding to the rejected hunk(s) from the given patch). A fix is available in versions 2.30.9, 2.31.8, 2.32.7, 2.33.8, 2.34.8, 2.35.8, 2.36.6, 2.37.7, 2.38.5, 2.39.3, and 2.40.1. As a workaround, avoid using `git apply` with `--reject` when applying patches from an untrusted source. Use `git apply --stat` to inspect a patch before applying; avoid applying one that create a conflict where a link corresponding to the `*.rej` file exists.

data.summary: Git is a revision control system. Prior to versions 2.30.9, 2.31.8, 2.32.7, 2.33.8, 2.34.8, 2.35.8, 2.36.6, 2.37.7, 2.38.5, 2.39.3, and 2.40.1, a specially crafted `.gitmodules` file with submodule URLs that are longer than 1024 characters can used to exploit a bug in `config.c::git_config_copy_or_rename_section_in_file()`. This bug can be used to inject arbitrary configuration into a user's `$GIT_DIR/config` when attempting to remove the configuration section associated with that submodule. When the attacker injects configuration values which specify executables to run (such as `core.pager`, `core.editor`, `core.sshCommand`, etc.) this can lead to a remote code execution. A fix A fix is available in versions 2.30.9, 2.31.8, 2.32.7, 2.33.8, 2.34.8, 2.35.8, 2.36.6, 2.37.7, 2.38.5, 2.39.3, and 2.40.1. As a workaround, avoid running `git submodule deinit` on untrusted repositories or without prior inspection of any submodule sections in `$GIT_DIR/config`.

more_details.description: Git is a revision control system. Prior to versions 2.30.9, 2.31.8, 2.32.7, 2.33.8, 2.34.8, 2.35.8, 2.36.6, 2.37.7, 2.38.5, 2.39.3, and 2.40.1, a specially crafted `.gitmodules` file with submodule URLs that are longer than 1024 characters can used to exploit a bug in `config.c::git_config_copy_or_rename_section_in_file()`. This bug can be used to inject arbitrary configuration into a user's `$GIT_DIR/config` when attempting to remove the configuration section associated with that submodule. When the attacker injects configuration values which specify executables to run (such as `core.pager`, `core.editor`, `core.sshCommand`, etc.) this can lead to a remote code execution. A fix A fix is available in versions 2.30.9, 2.31.8, 2.32.7, 2.33.8, 2.34.8, 2.35.8, 2.36.6, 2.37.7, 2.38.5, 2.39.3, and 2.40.1. As a workaround, avoid running `git submodule deinit` on untrusted repositories or without prior inspection of any submodule sections in `$GIT_DIR/config`.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: A design problem in Git may lead to arbitrary configuration injection and possibly to remote code execution when processing crafted repositories.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploiting the issue requires the user to interact with the vulnerable software
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: To exploit this vulnerability the user must run one of the following legitimate git commands, after initializing a malicious submodule: `git submodule deinit`, `git config --rename-section`, or `git config --remove-section`.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
The attacker must craft the `.gitmodules ` file and push it to a Git repository that the victim machine or user would clone or pull.
Also, the attacker needs to convince the user initialize a submodule and then run one of the git commands that trigger the issue using a crafted error message.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The published PoC demonstrates remote code execution.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Exploiting the issue might lead to remote code execution.

data.summary: A flaw was found in glibc. In an uncommon situation, the gaih_inet function may use memory that has been freed, resulting in an application crash. This issue is only exploitable when the getaddrinfo function is called and the hosts database in /etc/nsswitch.conf is configured with SUCCESS=continue or SUCCESS=merge.

more_details.description: A flaw was found in glibc. In an uncommon situation, the gaih_inet function may use memory that has been freed, resulting in an application crash. This issue is only exploitable when the getaddrinfo function is called and the hosts database in /etc/nsswitch.conf is configured with SUCCESS=continue or SUCCESS=merge.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: A use-after-free vulnerability in the `getaddrinfo` function of glibc may lead to denial of service when a non-default nsswitch.conf file is used
high_profile_info.Resolution:
##### Deployment mitigations

In `nsswitch.conf`, remove any `success=continue` and  `success=merge` directives under the `hosts` line

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are either extremely common or nonexistent (always exploitable)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The vulnerability is only exploitable when `getaddrinfo` is called

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
The vulnerability is only exploitable if a **non-default** `nsswitch.conf` file is used, where one of the following lines is present -
* `hosts: ... success=continue...`
* `hosts: ... success=merge ...`

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: No high-impact exploit or technical writeup were published, and exploitation of the issue with high impact is either non-trivial or completely unproven
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Exploitation requires triggering a use-after-free beyond the scope of a single function. The use-after-free has not been proven to be able to cause code execution.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: CVSS does not reflect the prerequisites for applicability.

data.summary: ** DISPUTED ** Xmlsoft Libxml2 v2.11.0 was discovered to contain an out-of-bounds read via the xmlSAX2StartElement() function at /libxml2/SAX2.c. This vulnerability allows attackers to cause a Denial of Service (DoS) via supplying a crafted XML file. NOTE: the vendor's position is that the product does not support the legacy SAX1 interface with custom callbacks; there is a crash even without crafted input.

more_details.description: ** DISPUTED ** Xmlsoft Libxml2 v2.11.0 was discovered to contain an out-of-bounds read via the xmlSAX2StartElement() function at /libxml2/SAX2.c. This vulnerability allows attackers to cause a Denial of Service (DoS) via supplying a crafted XML file. NOTE: the vendor's position is that the product does not support the legacy SAX1 interface with custom callbacks; there is a crash even without crafted input.

data.summary:
A failure in the -fstack-protector feature in GCC-based toolchains 
that target AArch64 allows an attacker to exploit an existing buffer 
overflow in dynamically-sized local variables in your application 
without this being detected. This stack-protector failure only applies 
to C99-style dynamically-sized local variables or those created using 
alloca(). The stack-protector operates as intended for statically-sized 
local variables.

The default behavior when the stack-protector 
detects an overflow is to terminate your application, resulting in 
controlled loss of availability. An attacker who can exploit a buffer 
overflow without triggering the stack-protector might be able to change 
program flow control to cause an uncontrolled loss of availability or to
 go further and affect confidentiality or integrity.
