data.summary: Incorrect Calculation of Buffer Size in GitHub repository vim/vim prior to 9.0.1378.

more_details.description: Incorrect Calculation of Buffer Size in GitHub repository vim/vim prior to 9.0.1378.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: (Non-Issue) Buffer overflow in vim leads to denial of service and potentially code execution when running crafted vim commands.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Vim](https://www.vim.org/) is a highly configurable text editor built to make creating and changing any kind of text very efficient.

It was discovered that running s specific string of vim commands (including `se`, `norm` and `sil`) will lead to a buffer overflow, which crashes the application.
However, this vulnerability has no security impact at all since -

1. If an attacker can run arbitrary vim commands, then the attacker can also execute arbitrary shell commands using the exclamation mark, and does not need this vulnerability to achieve code execution. For example running the vim command `!ls` will execute the shell command `ls`.

2. The buffer overflow is a `memset` with a negative size (leads to a huge overflow) in which the attacker does not control the overwritten data. This can only lead to denial of service. Crashing a forked client process such as vim does not have any security impact.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: This vulnerability has no security impact since if an attacker can run arbitrary vim commands, then the attacker can also execute arbitrary shell commands using the exclamation mark, and does not need this vulnerability to achieve code execution

data.summary: There's a flaw in urllib's AbstractBasicAuthHandler class. An attacker who controls a malicious HTTP server that an HTTP client (such as web browser) connects to, could trigger a Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDOS) during an authentication request with a specially crafted payload that is sent by the server to the client. The greatest threat that this flaw poses is to application availability.

data.summary: Python wsgiref.headers.Headers HTTP Response Splitting

more_details.description: Python contains a flaw in wsgiref.headers.Headers that is triggered as CRLF (Carriage Return and Line Feed) character sequences are not properly sanitized before being included in HTTP responses. This allows a remote attacker to inject additional headers into responses to conduct HTTP response splitting attacks.

data.summary:
A failure in the -fstack-protector feature in GCC-based toolchains 
that target AArch64 allows an attacker to exploit an existing buffer 
overflow in dynamically-sized local variables in your application 
without this being detected. This stack-protector failure only applies 
to C99-style dynamically-sized local variables or those created using 
alloca(). The stack-protector operates as intended for statically-sized 
local variables.

The default behavior when the stack-protector 
detects an overflow is to terminate your application, resulting in 
controlled loss of availability. An attacker who can exploit a buffer 
overflow without triggering the stack-protector might be able to change 
program flow control to cause an uncontrolled loss of availability or to
 go further and affect confidentiality or integrity.

controlled loss of availability. An attacker who can exploit a buffer 
overflow without triggering the stack-protector might be able to change 
program flow control to cause an uncontrolled loss of availability or to
 go further and affect confidentiality or integrity.

data.summary: The e-mail module of Python 0 - 2.7.18, 3.x - 3.11 incorrectly parses e-mail addresses which contain a special character. This vulnerability allows attackers to send messages from e-ail addresses that would otherwise be rejected.

data.summary: The email module of Python through 3.11.3 incorrectly parses e-mail addresses that contain a special character. The wrong portion of an RFC2822 header is identified as the value of the addr-spec. In some applications, an attacker can bypass a protection mechanism in which application access is granted only after verifying receipt of e-mail to a specific domain (e.g., only @company.example.com addresses may be used for signup). This occurs in email/_parseaddr.py in recent versions of Python.

data.summary: ** DISPUTED ** libxml2 through 2.11.5 has a use-after-free that can only occur after a certain memory allocation fails. This occurs in xmlUnlinkNode in tree.c. NOTE: the vendor's position is "I don't think these issues are critical enough to warrant a CVE ID ... because an attacker typically can't control when memory allocations fail."

data.summary:
Issue summary: Checking excessively long DH keys or parameters may be very slow.

Impact summary: Applications that use the functions DH_check(), DH_check_ex()
or EVP_PKEY_param_check() to check a DH key or DH parameters may experience long
delays. Where the key or parameters that are being checked have been obtained
from an untrusted source this may lead to a Denial of Service.

The function DH_check() performs various checks on DH parameters. After fixing
CVE-2023-3446 it was discovered that a large q parameter value can also trigger
an overly long computation during some of these checks. A correct q value,
if present, cannot be larger than the modulus p parameter, thus it is
unnecessary to perform these checks if q is larger than p.

An application that calls DH_check() and supplies a key or parameters obtained
from an untrusted source could be vulnerable to a Denial of Service attack.

The function DH_check() is itself called by a number of other OpenSSL functions.
An application calling any of those other functions may similarly be affected.
The other functions affected by this are DH_check_ex() and
EVP_PKEY_param_check().

Also vulnerable are the OpenSSL dhparam and pkeyparam command line applications
when using the "-check" option.

The OpenSSL SSL/TLS implementation is not affected by this issue.

The OpenSSL 3.0 and 3.1 FIPS providers are not affected by this issue.

data.summary: GNU Wget through 1.21.1 does not omit the Authorization header upon a redirect to a different origin, a related issue to CVE-2018-1000007.

data.summary: lib/kadm5/kadm_rpc_xdr.c in MIT Kerberos 5 (aka krb5) before 1.20.2 and 1.21.x before 1.21.1 frees an uninitialized pointer. A remote authenticated user can trigger a kadmind crash. This occurs because _xdr_kadm5_principal_ent_rec does not validate the relationship between n_key_data and the key_data array count.

data.summary: An issue was discovered in Python before 3.8.18, 3.9.x before 3.9.18, 3.10.x before 3.10.13, and 3.11.x before 3.11.5. It primarily affects servers (such as HTTP servers) that use TLS client authentication. If a TLS server-side socket is created, receives data into the socket buffer, and then is closed quickly, there is a brief window where the SSLSocket instance will detect the socket as "not connected" and won't initiate a handshake, but buffered data will still be readable from the socket buffer. This data will not be authenticated if the server-side TLS peer is expecting client certificate authentication, and is indistinguishable from valid TLS stream data. Data is limited in size to the amount that will fit in the buffer. (The TLS connection cannot directly be used for data exfiltration because the vulnerable code path requires that the connection be closed on initialization of the SSLSocket.)

(The TLS connection cannot directly be used for data exfiltration because the vulnerable code path requires that the connection be closed on initialization of the SSLSocket.)

more_details.description: An issue was discovered in Python before 3.8.18, 3.9.x before 3.9.18, 3.10.x before 3.10.13, and 3.11.x before 3.11.5. It primarily affects servers (such as HTTP servers) that use TLS client authentication. If a TLS server-side socket is created, receives data into the socket buffer, and then is closed quickly, there is a brief window where the SSLSocket instance will detect the socket as "not connected" and won't initiate a handshake, but buffered data will still be readable from the socket buffer. This data will not be authenticated if the server-side TLS peer is expecting client certificate authentication, and is indistinguishable from valid TLS stream data. Data is limited in size to the amount that will fit in the buffer. (The TLS connection cannot directly be used for data exfiltration because the vulnerable code path requires that the connection be closed on initialization of the SSLSocket.)

data.summary: Sudo before 1.9.13 does not escape control characters in sudoreplay output.

data.summary: A cleartext transmission of sensitive information vulnerability exists in curl <v7.88.0 that could cause HSTS functionality to behave incorrectly when multiple URLs are requested in parallel. Using its HSTS support, curl can be instructed to use HTTPS instead of using an insecure clear-text HTTP step even when HTTP is provided in the URL. This HSTS mechanism would however surprisingly fail when multiple transfers are done in parallel as the HSTS cache file gets overwritten by the most recentlycompleted transfer. A later HTTP-only transfer to the earlier host name would then *not* get upgraded properly to HSTS.

data.summary: An authentication bypass vulnerability exists in libcurl <8.0.0 in the FTP connection reuse feature that can result in wrong credentials being used during subsequent transfers. Previously created connections are kept in a connection pool for reuse if they match the current setup. However, certain FTP settings such as CURLOPT_FTP_ACCOUNT, CURLOPT_FTP_ALTERNATIVE_TO_USER, CURLOPT_FTP_SSL_CCC, and CURLOPT_USE_SSL were not included in the configuration match checks, causing them to match too easily. This could lead to libcurl using the wrong credentials when performing a transfer, potentially allowing unauthorized access to sensitive information.

more_details.description: An authentication bypass vulnerability exists in libcurl <8.0.0 in the FTP connection reuse feature that can result in wrong credentials being used during subsequent transfers. Previously created connections are kept in a connection pool for reuse if they match the current setup. However, certain FTP settings such as CURLOPT_FTP_ACCOUNT, CURLOPT_FTP_ALTERNATIVE_TO_USER, CURLOPT_FTP_SSL_CCC, and CURLOPT_USE_SSL were not included in the configuration match checks, causing them to match too easily. This could lead to libcurl using the wrong credentials when performing a transfer, potentially allowing unauthorized access to sensitive information.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: FTP connection reuse in curl may lead to authentication bypass when using specific FTP options.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Curl](https://curl.se/) is a command-line tool for transferring data from or to a server, using various protocols like HTTP, FTP, SMTP, and more.
libcurl can reuse a previously created FTP connection even when one or more options had been changed that could have made the effective FTP user a different one, thus leading to doing the second transfer with the wrong credentials.

Specifically, connecting to the same FTP server while changing one of the following options -

* `CURLOPT_FTP_ACCOUNT`
* `CURLOPT_FTP_ALTERNATIVE_TO_USER`
* `CURLOPT_FTP_SSL_CCC`
* `CURLOPT_USE_SSL`

will erroneously re-use a previously cached FTP connection (if the previous connection has been made from the same process), which is unexpected.
Note that while these options may affect the effective FTP user, these options are not usually used to specify the desired FTP user. The desired FTP user and password are set by the following options, which are not vulnerable to this issue (using different values for these options will invalidate cached connections) -
* CURLOPT_USERNAME
* CURLOPT_PASSWORD
* CURLOPT_USERPWD

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
The impact of exploiting the issue depends on the context of surrounding software. A severe impact such as RCE is not guaranteed.
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: As with any authorization bypass, the impact of the issue depends on the actions performed by the re-used FTP connection. Specifically, a re-used connection may still give access erroneously to attackers that lack valid credentials

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The maintainers referred to this issue as "probably never hurt a single user and is a rather contrived use case to trigger it"

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The CVSS does not take into account the high attack complexity & per-target research needed to exploit this issue

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
The CVE is only exploitable when a single process uses libcurl to perform multiple FTP connections with obscure flags that may change the effective FTP user - 
* `CURLOPT_FTP_ACCOUNT`
* `CURLOPT_FTP_ALTERNATIVE_TO_USER`
* `CURLOPT_FTP_SSL_CCC`
* `CURLOPT_USE_SSL`

These flags are not the common flags used for FTP authentication.
An attacker would usually not have control of the usage of these flags or their values.

data.summary:
Issue summary: Checking excessively long DH keys or parameters may be very slow.

Impact summary: Applications that use the functions DH_check(), DH_check_ex()
or EVP_PKEY_param_check() to check a DH key or DH parameters may experience long
delays. Where the key or parameters that are being checked have been obtained
from an untrusted source this may lead to a Denial of Service.

The function DH_check() performs various checks on DH parameters. One of those
checks confirms that the modulus ('p' parameter) is not too large. Trying to use
a very large modulus is slow and OpenSSL will not normally use a modulus which
is over 10,000 bits in length.

However the DH_check() function checks numerous aspects of the key or parameters
that have been supplied. Some of those checks use the supplied modulus value
even if it has already been found to be too large.

An application that calls DH_check() and supplies a key or parameters obtained
from an untrusted source could be vulernable to a Denial of Service attack.

The function DH_check() is itself called by a number of other OpenSSL functions.
An application calling any of those other functions may similarly be affected.
The other functions affected by this are DH_check_ex() and
EVP_PKEY_param_check().

Also vulnerable are the OpenSSL dhparam and pkeyparam command line applications
when using the '-check' option.

The OpenSSL SSL/TLS implementation is not affected by this issue.
The OpenSSL 3.0 and 3.1 FIPS providers are not affected by this issue.

data.summary: An authentication bypass vulnerability exists in libcurl prior to v8.0.0 where it reuses a previously established SSH connection despite the fact that an SSH option was modified, which should have prevented reuse. libcurl maintains a pool of previously used connections to reuse them for subsequent transfers if the configurations match. However, two SSH settings were omitted from the configuration check, allowing them to match easily, potentially leading to the reuse of an inappropriate connection.

data.summary: An improper certificate validation vulnerability exists in curl <v8.1.0 in the way it supports matching of wildcard patterns when listed as "Subject Alternative Name" in TLS server certificates. curl can be built to use its own name matching function for TLS rather than one provided by a TLS library. This private wildcard matching function would match IDN (International Domain Name) hosts incorrectly and could as a result accept patterns that otherwise should mismatch. IDN hostnames are converted to puny code before used for certificate checks. Puny coded names always start with `xn--` and should not be allowed to pattern match, but the wildcard check in curl could still check for `x*`, which would match even though the IDN name most likely contained nothing even resembling an `x`.

more_details.description: An improper certificate validation vulnerability exists in curl <v8.1.0 in the way it supports matching of wildcard patterns when listed as "Subject Alternative Name" in TLS server certificates. curl can be built to use its own name matching function for TLS rather than one provided by a TLS library. This private wildcard matching function would match IDN (International Domain Name) hosts incorrectly and could as a result accept patterns that otherwise should mismatch. IDN hostnames are converted to puny code before used for certificate checks. Puny coded names always start with `xn--` and should not be allowed to pattern match, but the wildcard check in curl could still check for `x*`, which would match even though the IDN name most likely contained nothing even resembling an `x`.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Improper certificate pattern matching in curl can lead to authentication bypass.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: An attacker could create a certificate with a partial wildcard in the International Domain Name (IDN) field

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The official project maintainers assigned a "Low" severity to this vulnerability

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
Certificates issued by Certificate Authorities for the public Internet are not allowed to use "partial" wildcards, thus completely avoiding this issue.

In many circumstances, the control of host names used and the wildcards used in issued certificates are controlled by the same entity, making this unlikely to actually become a problem.

Puny coded names always start with `xn--` and should not be allowed to pattern match, but the wildcard check in curl could still check for `x*`, which would match even though the IDN name most likely contained nothing even resembling an `x`.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Improper certificate pattern matching in curl can lead to authentication bypass.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: An attacker could create a certificate with a partial wildcard in the International Domain Name (IDN) field

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The official project maintainers assigned a "Low" severity to this vulnerability

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
Certificates issued by Certificate Authorities for the public Internet are not allowed to use "partial" wildcards, thus completely avoiding this issue.

In many circumstances, the control of host names used and the wildcards used in issued certificates are controlled by the same entity, making this unlikely to actually become a problem.

data.summary: An authentication bypass vulnerability exists in libcurl prior to v8.0.0 where it reuses a previously established SSH connection despite the fact that an SSH option was modified, which should have prevented reuse. libcurl maintains a pool of previously used connections to reuse them for subsequent transfers if the configurations match. However, two SSH settings were omitted from the configuration check, allowing them to match easily, potentially leading to the reuse of an inappropriate connection.

However, two SSH settings were omitted from the configuration check, allowing them to match easily, potentially leading to the reuse of an inappropriate connection.

data.summary: A vulnerability was found in Linux Kernel. It has been classified as problematic. This affects the function find_prog_by_sec_insn of the file tools/lib/bpf/libbpf.c of the component BPF. The manipulation leads to null pointer dereference. It is recommended to apply a patch to fix this issue. The identifier VDB-211749 was assigned to this vulnerability.

data.summary: An authentication bypass vulnerability exists libcurl <8.0.0 in the connection reuse feature which can reuse previously established connections with incorrect user permissions due to a failure to check for changes in the CURLOPT_GSSAPI_DELEGATION option. This vulnerability affects krb5/kerberos/negotiate/GSSAPI transfers and could potentially result in unauthorized access to sensitive information. The safest option is to not reuse connections if the CURLOPT_GSSAPI_DELEGATION option has been changed.

more_details.description: An authentication bypass vulnerability exists libcurl <8.0.0 in the connection reuse feature which can reuse previously established connections with incorrect user permissions due to a failure to check for changes in the CURLOPT_GSSAPI_DELEGATION option. This vulnerability affects krb5/kerberos/negotiate/GSSAPI transfers and could potentially result in unauthorized access to sensitive information. The safest option is to not reuse connections if the CURLOPT_GSSAPI_DELEGATION option has been changed.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Connection reuse in curl may lead to authentication bypass when changing GSS delegation between requests.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Curl](https://curl.se/) is a command-line tool for transferring data from or to a server, using various protocols like HTTP, FTP, SMTP, and more.
GSS-API delegation is a mechanism where a server can obtain credentials from a client and use them to access resources on behalf of the client. This allows the server to act as a proxy for the client, using the client's credentials to access resources that the client may not have direct access to.

To delegate credentials, the client establishes a GSS-API security context with the server, and if the client supports delegation and has valid credentials, sends a "forwardable" ticket to the server. The server can then use this ticket to access resources on behalf of the client. 

libcurl can reuse a previously created connection even when the delegation option had been changed which could have made the effective user no longer have access, thus leading to doing the second transfer with the wrong permissions.

Specifically, connecting to the same server while changing the following setting - `CURLOPT_GSSAPI_DELEGATION` (or `--delegation` in curl command line) will erroneously re-use a previously cached connection (if the previous connection has been made from the same process), which is unexpected.

GSS-API delegation can also be used with Kerberos. When using Kerberos with GSS-API delegation, the client obtains a Kerberos ticket-granting ticket (TGT) during authentication, which can be used by the server to obtain a service ticket for accessing resources on behalf of the client. The server can then use the service ticket to access resources on the client's behalf without requiring the client to re-authenticate.

It is highly unlikely that a user would suddenly no longer have access because of a change in delegation in the second request.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The impact of exploiting the issue depends on the context of surrounding software. A severe impact such as RCE is not guaranteed.
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: As with any authorization bypass, the impact of the issue depends on the actions performed by the re-used connection. Specifically, a re-used connection may still give access erroneously to attackers that lack valid credentials.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
The CVE is only exploitable when a single process uses libcurl or curl to perform multiple connections with an obscure flag that may change the effective delegation value - `CURLOPT_GSSAPI_DELEGATION` or `--delegation` in curl's command line.

This flag is not commonly used and it's highly unlikely that two requests to the same server would have different delegations.
An attacker would usually not have control of the usage of these flags or their values.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: An exploit that demonstrates authentication bypass is available.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The maintainers referred to this issue as a security bug "mostly in theory".

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The CVSS does not take into account the high attack complexity & per-target research needed to exploit this issue.

data.summary: A flaw was found in Python, specifically in the FTP (File Transfer Protocol) client library in PASV (passive) mode. The issue is how the FTP client trusts the host from the PASV response by default. This flaw allows an attacker to set up a malicious FTP server that can trick FTP clients into connecting back to a given IP address and port. This vulnerability could lead to FTP client scanning ports, which otherwise would not have been possible.

data.summary: A flaw was found in glibc. In an extremely rare situation, the getaddrinfo function may access memory that has been freed, resulting in an application crash. This issue is only exploitable when a NSS module implements only the _nss_*_gethostbyname2_r and _nss_*_getcanonname_r hooks without implementing the _nss_*_gethostbyname3_r hook. The resolved name should return a large number of IPv6 and IPv4, and the call to the getaddrinfo function should have the AF_INET6 address family with AI_CANONNAME, AI_ALL and AI_V4MAPPED as flags.

data.summary: Under some circumstances, this weakness allows a user who has access to run the “ps” utility on a machine, the ability to write almost unlimited amounts of unfiltered data into the process heap.

data.summary: There's a flaw in Python 3's pydoc. A local or adjacent attacker who discovers or is able to convince another local or adjacent user to start a pydoc server could access the server and use it to disclose sensitive information belonging to the other user that they would not normally be able to access. The highest risk of this flaw is to data confidentiality. This flaw affects Python versions before 3.8.9, Python versions before 3.9.3 and Python versions before 3.10.0a7.

data.summary: A flaw was found in Python, specifically in the FTP (File Transfer Protocol) client library in PASV (passive) mode. The issue is how the FTP client trusts the host from the PASV response by default. This flaw allows an attacker to set up a malicious FTP server that can trick FTP clients into connecting back to a given IP address and port. This vulnerability could lead to FTP client scanning ports, which otherwise would not have been possible.

data.summary: An issue was discovered in Python before 3.8.18, 3.9.x before 3.9.18, 3.10.x before 3.10.13, and 3.11.x before 3.11.5. It primarily affects servers (such as HTTP servers) that use TLS client authentication. If a TLS server-side socket is created, receives data into the socket buffer, and then is closed quickly, there is a brief window where the SSLSocket instance will detect the socket as "not connected" and won't initiate a handshake, but buffered data will still be readable from the socket buffer. This data will not be authenticated if the server-side TLS peer is expecting client certificate authentication, and is indistinguishable from valid TLS stream data. Data is limited in size to the amount that will fit in the buffer. (The TLS connection cannot directly be used for data exfiltration because the vulnerable code path requires that the connection be closed on initialization of the SSLSocket.)

Data is limited in size to the amount that will fit in the buffer. (The TLS connection cannot directly be used for data exfiltration because the vulnerable code path requires that the connection be closed on initialization of the SSLSocket.)

data.summary: A flaw was found in glibc. In an uncommon situation, the gaih_inet function may use memory that has been freed, resulting in an application crash. This issue is only exploitable when the getaddrinfo function is called and the hosts database in /etc/nsswitch.conf is configured with SUCCESS=continue or SUCCESS=merge.

more_details.description: A flaw was found in glibc. In an uncommon situation, the gaih_inet function may use memory that has been freed, resulting in an application crash. This issue is only exploitable when the getaddrinfo function is called and the hosts database in /etc/nsswitch.conf is configured with SUCCESS=continue or SUCCESS=merge.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: A use-after-free vulnerability in the `getaddrinfo` function of glibc may lead to denial of service when a non-default nsswitch.conf file is used
high_profile_info.Resolution:
##### Deployment mitigations

In `nsswitch.conf`, remove any `success=continue` and  `success=merge` directives under the `hosts` line

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are either extremely common or nonexistent (always exploitable)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The vulnerability is only exploitable when `getaddrinfo` is called

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
The vulnerability is only exploitable if a **non-default** `nsswitch.conf` file is used, where one of the following lines is present -
* `hosts: ... success=continue...`
* `hosts: ... success=merge ...`

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: No high-impact exploit or technical writeup were published, and exploitation of the issue with high impact is either non-trivial or completely unproven
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Exploitation requires triggering a use-after-free beyond the scope of a single function. The use-after-free has not been proven to be able to cause code execution.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: CVSS does not reflect the prerequisites for applicability.

data.summary: Heap buffer overflow vulnerability in binutils readelf before 2.40 via function find_section_in_set in file readelf.c.

more_details.description: Heap buffer overflow vulnerability in binutils readelf before 2.40 via function find_section_in_set in file readelf.c.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Buffer overread in binutils leads to denial of service when reading debug information from a crafted ELF.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
The GNU [Binutils](https://www.gnu.org/software/binutils/) are a collection of binary tools. The main ones are: ld - the GNU linker, as - the GNU assembler and gold - a new, faster, ELF only linker. Most of these programs use BFD, the Binary File Descriptor library, to do low-level manipulation.
It was discovered that the BFD library can cause an out-of-bounds read when reading crafted debug info (DWARF info) from an ELF executable
For example - this can cause the `readelf` utility to crash when reading a crafted executable -
`readelf -w ./PoC`

Note that this issue cannot causes a 1-byte out-of-bounds write (overwriting a NULL terminator) which leads to an out-of-bounds read. Therefore - exploitation cannot lead to code execution in any case.
This leads to a very low severity since crashing a forked client process (ex. `readelf` or any other executable from binutils) has a negligible security impact.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: A public PoC demonstrates DoS when running `readelf` on a crafted ELF

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Crashing a forked client process (ex. objdump or any other executable from binutils) has a negligible security impact. In addition, a 1-byte overread is unlikely to cause a real-world crash or meaningful data leak.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: NVD wrongly classifies this issue as a buffer overflow, when in fact this issue is an out-of-bounds read and therefore cannot lead to code execution in any case.

data.summary: Use After Free in GitHub repository vim/vim prior to 9.0.1857.

more_details.description: Use After Free in GitHub repository vim/vim prior to 9.0.1857.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: (Non-Issue) Use-after-free in vim leads to denial of service and potentially code execution when running crafted vim commands.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Vim](https://www.vim.org/) is a free, open-source, screen-based text editor program for Unix.
Vim has an `Ex mode` that allows entering Ex commands and is designed for Batch processing.

The Ex, or colon, commands are based on the line editor named ex. In general, they operate on the document as a whole, or large portions of it (although there are commands to perform essentially every editing task).

It was discovered that when sourcing a file using Vim `Ex mode`, a use-after-free may occur, which leads to a denial of service.

`vim` can be run with one or more flags. These flags include, but are not limited to:

* `-e`: With the `-e` flag, the user enters Ex mode. The Ex mode is similar to the command line mode as it also allows you to enter Ex commands.
* `-s`: With the `-s` flag, the user can silence the ex mode, to support batch commands.
* `-S`: With the `-S` flag, the user sources the file after loading it.

The issue requires the victim to run an attacker's specially crafted file in `Ex mode` and source it as well.
An example of a vulnerable command line:
`vim -e -s -S {malicious_file}`

Opening files with vim in this specific mode is highly unlikely.

This vulnerability has no security impact at all since if an attacker can run arbitrary vim commands, then the attacker can also execute arbitrary shell commands using the exclamation mark, and does not need this vulnerability to achieve code execution. For example running the vim command `!ls` will execute the shell command `ls`.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The CVSS does not reflect the contextual prerequisites required to exploit the vulnerability.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: An exploit has been published along with the original report.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: To exploit this issue Vim must be run in `Ex mode` and also source the malicious text file.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: This vulnerability has no security impact since if an attacker can run arbitrary vim commands, then the attacker can also execute arbitrary shell commands using the exclamation mark, and does not need this vulnerability to achieve code execution.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploiting the issue requires the user to interact with the vulnerable software
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The victim must open the attacker's crafted text file in Vim.

data.summary: Use After Free in GitHub repository vim/vim prior to 9.0.1857.

more_details.description: Use After Free in GitHub repository vim/vim prior to 9.0.1857.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: (Non-Issue) Use-after-free in vim leads to denial of service and potentially code execution when running crafted vim commands.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Vim](https://www.vim.org/) is a free, open-source, screen-based text editor program for Unix.
Vim has an `Ex mode` that allows entering Ex commands and is designed for Batch processing.

The Ex, or colon, commands are based on the line editor named ex. In general, they operate on the document as a whole, or large portions of it (although there are commands to perform essentially every editing task).

It was discovered that when sourcing a file using Vim `Ex mode`, a use-after-free may occur, which leads to a denial of service.

`vim` can be run with one or more flags. These flags include, but are not limited to:

* `-e`: With the `-e` flag, the user enters Ex mode. The Ex mode is similar to the command line mode as it also allows you to enter Ex commands.
* `-s`: With the `-s` flag, the user can silence the ex mode, to support batch commands.
* `-S`: With the `-S` flag, the user sources the file after loading it.

The issue requires the victim to run an attacker's specially crafted file in `Ex mode` and source it as well.
An example of a vulnerable command line:
`vim -e -s -S {malicious_file}`

Opening files with vim in this specific mode is highly unlikely.

This vulnerability has no security impact at all since if an attacker can run arbitrary vim commands, then the attacker can also execute arbitrary shell commands using the exclamation mark, and does not need this vulnerability to achieve code execution. For example running the vim command `!ls` will execute the shell command `ls`.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The CVSS does not reflect the contextual prerequisites required to exploit the vulnerability.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: An exploit has been published along with the original report.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: To exploit this issue Vim must be run in `Ex mode` and also source the malicious text file.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: This vulnerability has no security impact since if an attacker can run arbitrary vim commands, then the attacker can also execute arbitrary shell commands using the exclamation mark, and does not need this vulnerability to achieve code execution.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploiting the issue requires the user to interact with the vulnerable software
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The victim must open the attacker's crafted text file in Vim.

data.summary:
In Git for Windows, the Windows port of Git, no localized messages are shipped with the installer. As a consequence, Git is expected not to localize messages at all, and skips the gettext initialization. However, due to a change in MINGW-packages, the `gettext()` function's implicit initialization no longer uses the runtime prefix but uses the hard-coded path `C:\mingw64\share\locale` to look for localized messages. And since any authenticated user has the permission to create folders in `C:\` (and since `C:\mingw64` does not typically exist), it is possible for low-privilege users to place fake messages in that location where `git.exe` will pick them up in version 2.40.1.

This vulnerability is relatively hard to exploit and requires social engineering. For example, a legitimate message at the end of a clone could be maliciously modified to ask the user to direct their web browser to a malicious website, and the user might think that the message comes from Git and is legitimate. It does require local write access by the attacker, though, which makes this attack vector less likely. Version 2.40.1 contains a patch for this issue. Some workarounds are available. Do not work on a Windows machine with shared accounts, or alternatively create a `C:\mingw64` folder and leave it empty. Users who have administrative rights may remove the permission to create folders in `C:\`.

However, due to a change in MINGW-packages, the `gettext()` function's implicit initialization no longer uses the runtime prefix but uses the hard-coded path `C:\mingw64\share\locale` to look for localized messages. And since any authenticated user has the permission to create folders in `C:\` (and since `C:\mingw64` does not typically exist), it is possible for low-privilege users to place fake messages in that location where `git.exe` will pick them up in version 2.40.1.

This vulnerability is relatively hard to exploit and requires social engineering. For example, a legitimate message at the end of a clone could be maliciously modified to ask the user to direct their web browser to a malicious website, and the user might think that the message comes from Git and is legitimate. It does require local write access by the attacker, though, which makes this attack vector less likely. Version 2.40.1 contains a patch for this issue. Some workarounds are available. Do not work on a Windows machine with shared accounts, or alternatively create a `C:\mingw64` folder and leave it empty. Users who have administrative rights may remove the permission to create folders in `C:\`.

data.summary: An issue was discovered in binutils libbfd.c 2.36 relating to the auxiliary symbol data allows attackers to read or write to system memory or cause a denial of service.

more_details.description: An issue was discovered in binutils libbfd.c 2.36 relating to the auxiliary symbol data allows attackers to read or write to system memory or cause a denial of service.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Buffer overread in binutils leads to denial of service when reading debug information from a crafted executable.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
The GNU [Binutils](https://www.gnu.org/software/binutils/) are a collection of binary tools. The main ones are: ld - the GNU linker, as - the GNU assembler and gold - a new, faster, ELF only linker. Most of these programs use BFD, the Binary File Descriptor library, to do low-level manipulation.
It was discovered that the BFD library can cause an out-of-bounds read when reading crafted debug info (auxiliary symbol data) from an executable file.
For example - this can cause the `nm-new` utility to crash when reading a crafted executable -
`nm-new -C -a -l --synthetic poc.bin `

Note that this issue cannot cause an out-of-bounds write (only an out-of-bounds read) and therefore cannot lead to code execution in any case.
In addition, the out-of-bounds read is a 1-byte read, making it unlikely to cause a crash or a meaningful data leak.
This leads to a very low severity since crashing a forked client process (ex. `nm-new` or any other executable from binutils) has a negligible security impact.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: NVD wrongly classifies this issue as a buffer overflow, when in fact this issue is an out-of-bounds read and therefore cannot lead to code execution in any case.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: A public PoC demonstrates DoS when running `nm-new` on a crafted ELF

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Crashing a forked client process (ex. objdump or any other executable from binutils) has a negligible security impact. In addition, a 1-byte overread is unlikely to cause a real-world crash or meaningful data leak.

data.summary: Python Modules/_operator.c _tscmp() Function Timing Side-channel Information Disclosure Weakness

data.summary: An information disclosure vulnerability exists in curl <v8.1.0 when doing HTTP(S) transfers, libcurl might erroneously use the read callback (`CURLOPT_READFUNCTION`) to ask for data to send, even when the `CURLOPT_POSTFIELDS` option has been set, if the same handle previously wasused to issue a `PUT` request which used that callback. This flaw may surprise the application and cause it to misbehave and either send off the wrong data or use memory after free or similar in the second transfer. The problem exists in the logic for a reused handle when it is (expected to be) changed from a PUT to a POST.

more_details.description: An information disclosure vulnerability exists in curl <v8.1.0 when doing HTTP(S) transfers, libcurl might erroneously use the read callback (`CURLOPT_READFUNCTION`) to ask for data to send, even when the `CURLOPT_POSTFIELDS` option has been set, if the same handle previously wasused to issue a `PUT` request which used that callback. This flaw may surprise the application and cause it to misbehave and either send off the wrong data or use memory after free or similar in the second transfer. The problem exists in the logic for a reused handle when it is (expected to be) changed from a PUT to a POST.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Handle reuse in libcurl may lead to context-dependent impact when sending a POST request after a PUT request.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The official project maintainers assigned a "Low" severity to this vulnerability

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
This flaw cannot be triggered with the command line tool, it requires using libcurl directly, and specifically calling the `curl_easy_setopt` API with the following flags one after another -
* `CURLOPT_READFUNCTION` - to set up a read callback that supplies data to the following PUT request
* `CURLOPT_PUT / CURLOPT_UPLOAD` - to perform a PUT request
* `CURLOPT_POSTFIELDS` - to (attempt to) supply data for the following POST request
* `CURLOPT_POST` - to perform a POST request (which will erroneously use the read callback previously set)

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The attacker must find a remote input to the victim application that makes it send a PUT request and subsequently a POST request, using libcurl

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The impact of exploiting the issue depends on the context of surrounding software. A severe impact such as RCE is not guaranteed.
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The impact of the vulnerability depends on the data supplied in the `CURLOPT_READFUNCTION` callback and the `CURLOPT_POSTFIELDS` data parameter. A possible impact is leakage of unintended data, since the callback is used for both the PUT and POST requests unintentionally (instead of just the PUT request)

This flaw may surprise the application and cause it to misbehave and either send off the wrong data or use memory after free or similar in the second transfer. The problem exists in the logic for a reused handle when it is (expected to be) changed from a PUT to a POST.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
This flaw cannot be triggered with the command line tool, it requires using libcurl directly, and specifically calling the `curl_easy_setopt` API with the following flags one after another -
* `CURLOPT_READFUNCTION` - to set up a read callback that supplies data to the following PUT request
* `CURLOPT_PUT / CURLOPT_UPLOAD` - to perform a PUT request
* `CURLOPT_POSTFIELDS` - to (attempt to) supply data for the following POST request
* `CURLOPT_POST` - to perform a POST request (which will erroneously use the read callback previously set)

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The attacker must find a remote input to the victim application that makes it send a PUT request and subsequently a POST request, using libcurl

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The impact of exploiting the issue depends on the context of surrounding software. A severe impact such as RCE is not guaranteed.
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The impact of the vulnerability depends on the data supplied in the `CURLOPT_READFUNCTION` callback and the `CURLOPT_POSTFIELDS` data parameter. A possible impact is leakage of unintended data, since the callback is used for both the PUT and POST requests unintentionally (instead of just the PUT request)

data.summary: An information disclosure vulnerability exists in curl <v8.1.0 when doing HTTP(S) transfers, libcurl might erroneously use the read callback (`CURLOPT_READFUNCTION`) to ask for data to send, even when the `CURLOPT_POSTFIELDS` option has been set, if the same handle previously wasused to issue a `PUT` request which used that callback. This flaw may surprise the application and cause it to misbehave and either send off the wrong data or use memory after free or similar in the second transfer. The problem exists in the logic for a reused handle when it is (expected to be) changed from a PUT to a POST.

more_details.description: An information disclosure vulnerability exists in curl <v8.1.0 when doing HTTP(S) transfers, libcurl might erroneously use the read callback (`CURLOPT_READFUNCTION`) to ask for data to send, even when the `CURLOPT_POSTFIELDS` option has been set, if the same handle previously wasused to issue a `PUT` request which used that callback. This flaw may surprise the application and cause it to misbehave and either send off the wrong data or use memory after free or similar in the second transfer. The problem exists in the logic for a reused handle when it is (expected to be) changed from a PUT to a POST.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Handle reuse in libcurl may lead to context-dependent impact when sending a POST request after a PUT request.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: (Non-Issue) Buffer overflow in vim leads to denial of service and potentially code execution when running crafted vim commands.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Vim](https://www.vim.org/) is a free, open-source, screen-based text editor program for Unix.
Vim has an `Ex mode` that allows entering Ex commands and is designed for Batch processing.

The Ex, or colon, commands are based on the line editor named ex. In general, they operate on the document as a whole, or large portions of it (although there are commands to perform essentially every editing task).

It was discovered that when sourcing a file using Vim `Ex mode`, a heap overflow may occur, which leads to a denial of service.

`vim` can be run with one or more flags. These flags include, but are not limited to:

* `-e`: With the `-e` flag, the user enters Ex mode. The Ex mode is similar to the command line mode as it also allows you to enter Ex commands.
* `-s`: With the `-s` flag, the user can silence the ex mode, to support batch commands.
* `-S`: With the `-S` flag, the user sources the file after loading it.

The issue requires the victim to run an attacker's specially crafted file in `Ex mode` and source it as well.
An example of a vulnerable command line:
`vim -e -s -S {malicious_file}`

Opening files with vim in this specific mode is highly unlikely.

This vulnerability has no security impact at all since if an attacker can run arbitrary vim commands, then the attacker can also execute arbitrary shell commands using the exclamation mark, and does not need this vulnerability to achieve code execution. For example running the vim command `!ls` will execute the shell command `ls`.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The CVSS does not reflect the contextual prerequisites required to exploit the vulnerability.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: This vulnerability has no security impact since if an attacker can run arbitrary vim commands, then the attacker can also execute arbitrary shell commands using the exclamation mark, and does not need this vulnerability to achieve code execution.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploiting the issue requires the user to interact with the vulnerable software
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The victim must open the attacker's crafted text file in Vim.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: To exploit this issue Vim must be run in `Ex mode` and also source the malicious text file.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: An exploit has been published along with the original report.

data.summary: A denial of service vulnerability exists in curl <v8.1.0 in the way libcurl provides several different backends for resolving host names, selected at build time. If it is built to use the synchronous resolver, it allows name resolves to time-out slow operations using `alarm()` and `siglongjmp()`. When doing this, libcurl used a global buffer that was not mutex protected and a multi-threaded application might therefore crash or otherwise misbehave.

data.summary: The HTTP/2 protocol allows a denial of service (server resource consumption) because request cancellation can reset many streams quickly, as exploited in the wild in August through October 2023.

more_details.description: The HTTP/2 protocol allows a denial of service (server resource consumption) because request cancellation can reset many streams quickly, as exploited in the wild in August through October 2023.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: A design problem in the implementation of the HTTP/2 protocol may lead to DoS and ease the possibility of DDoS in web server applications by abusing request cancellation.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[The HTTP (Hypertext Transfer Protocol)](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP) is a fundamental protocol of the World Wide Web, enabling the exchange of data between a client (typically a web browser) and a server. It defines the rules for requesting and transmitting web pages and other resources over the internet. Request and response messages are exchanged as a stream of ASCII characters, sent over a reliable transport layer like TCP.

[HTTP/2](https://http2.github.io/) is a modern network protocol designed to improve the performance and efficiency of web communication. It replaces the older HTTP/1.1 protocol and introduces features like header compression and enhanced request cancellation mechanisms, which collectively enhance the speed and responsiveness of websites.

This request cancellation mechanism allows clients to terminate unnecessary or redundant requests without waiting for a server's response, reducing network congestion and further improving the overall responsiveness of web applications.

HTTP/2 resolves numerous concerns found in HTTP/1.1 by organizing each HTTP message into a series of HTTP/2 frames. These frames include type, length, flags, stream identifier (ID), and payload. The stream ID is essential in clearly associating specific bytes on the network with their corresponding messages, facilitating secure multiplexing and concurrent processing. These streams are bidirectional, enabling clients to transmit frames, and servers to respond with frames using the same ID.

As detailed in [this technical analysis](https://blog.cloudflare.com/technical-breakdown-http2-rapid-reset-ddos-attack/), there's a vulnerability in the way request cancellation is implemented. The flaw lies in the process of sending an excessive number of requests (specifically, `HEADERS` frames), each immediately followed by a request cancellation frame utilizing the `RST_STREAM` frame. This sequence rapidly leads to a substantial consumption of server-side resources. Consequently, this vulnerability amplifies the risk of Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks, making it easier to overwhelm and exhaust the server's available resources.

A lot of server applications are vulnerable to the Http/2 Rapid Reset attack.
However, note that HTTP/2 must be enabled, which is not the default configuration on most applications (excluding nghttp2 for example).
A non-exhaustive list of these vulnerable web applications:
```
- Tomcat
- Jetty
- NGINX on certain conditions
- nghttp2
- Netty
```

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has been reported to be actively exploited in public networks
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Cloudflare identified this vulnerability being exploited in a DDoS attack of unprecedented scale on August 25, 2023, which surpassed their previous largest recorded attack by almost threefold.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The attacker should attack a web server application with HTTP/2 protocol enabled and no (or a high) keepalive-requests options.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: A [PoC exists](https://github.com/imabee101/CVE-2023-44487) for this issue

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: This issue can lead to DoS on popular server applications using HTTP/2 protocol and ease the possibility of DDoS attack.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has multiple mentions in general media
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The vulnerability received extensive media coverage from Google, Cloudflare, and more.

data.summary: NULL Pointer Dereference in GitHub repository vim/vim prior to 9.0.1402.

more_details.description: NULL Pointer Dereference in GitHub repository vim/vim prior to 9.0.1402.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: (Non-Issue) A NULL pointer dereference in vim leads to denial of service and potentially code execution when running crafted vim commands.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Vim](https://www.vim.org/) is a free, open-source, screen-based text editor program for Unix.
Vim has an `Ex mode` that allows entering Ex commands and is designed for Batch processing.

The Ex, or colon, commands are based on the line editor named ex. In general, they operate on the document as a whole, or large portions of it (although there are commands to perform essentially every editing task).

It was discovered that when sourcing a file using Vim `Ex mode`, a heap overflow may occur, which leads to a denial of service.

`vim` can be run with one or more flags. These flags include, but are not limited to:

* `-e`: With the `-e` flag, the user enters Ex mode. The Ex mode is similar to the command line mode as it also allows you to enter Ex commands.
* `-s`: With the `-s` flag, the user can silence the ex mode, to support batch commands.
* `-S`: With the `-S` flag, the user sources the file after loading it.

The issue requires the victim to run an attacker's specially crafted file in `Ex mode` and source it as well.
An example of a vulnerable command line:
`vim -e -s -S {malicious_file}`

Opening files with vim in this specific mode is highly unlikely.

This vulnerability has no security impact at all since if an attacker can run arbitrary vim commands, then the attacker can also execute arbitrary shell commands using the exclamation mark, and does not need this vulnerability to achieve code execution. For example running the vim command `!ls` will execute the shell command `ls`.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: An exploit has been published along with the original report.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The CVSS does not reflect the contextual prerequisites required to exploit the vulnerability.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploiting the issue requires the user to interact with the vulnerable software
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The victim must open the attacker's crafted text file in Vim.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: This vulnerability has no security impact since if an attacker can run arbitrary vim commands, then the attacker can also execute arbitrary shell commands using the exclamation mark, and does not need this vulnerability to achieve code execution.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: To exploit this issue Vim must be run in `Ex mode` and also source the malicious text file.

data.summary: Heap based buffer overflow in binutils-gdb/bfd/libbfd.c in bfd_getl64.

more_details.description: Heap based buffer overflow in binutils-gdb/bfd/libbfd.c in bfd_getl64.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Buffer overread in binutils leads to denial of service when reading debug information from a crafted ELF.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
The GNU [Binutils](https://www.gnu.org/software/binutils/) are a collection of binary tools. The main ones are: ld - the GNU linker, as - the GNU assembler and gold - a new, faster, ELF only linker. Most of these programs use BFD, the Binary File Descriptor library, to do low-level manipulation.
It was discovered that the BFD library can cause an out-of-bounds read when reading crafted debug info (DWARF info) from an ELF file or any other source.
For example - this can cause the `objdump` utility to crash when reading a crafted ELF.

Note that this issue cannot cause an out-of-bounds write (only an out-of-bounds read) and therefore cannot lead to code execution in any case.
This leads to a very low severity since crashing a forked client process (ex. `objdump` or any other executable from binutils) has a negligible security impact.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Crashing a forked client process (ex. objdump or any other executable from binutils) has a negligible security impact.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: NVD wrongly classifies this issue as a buffer overflow, when in fact this issue is an out-of-bounds read and therefore cannot lead to code execution in any case.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: A public PoC demonstrates DoS when running `objdump` on a crafted ELF

data.summary: HTTP::Tiny before 0.083, a Perl core module since 5.13.9 and available standalone on CPAN, has an insecure default TLS configuration where users must opt in to verify certificates.

more_details.description: HTTP::Tiny before 0.083, a Perl core module since 5.13.9 and available standalone on CPAN, has an insecure default TLS configuration where users must opt in to verify certificates.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Missing TLS check in HTTP::Tiny allows network attackers to perform man-in-the-middle attacks when performing SSL requests.
high_profile_info.Resolution:
##### Development mitigations

Enable the `verify_SSL` flag when initializing HTTP::Tiny -

```perl
$http = HTTP::Tiny->new(verify_SSL=>1);
```

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The impact of exploiting the issue depends on the context of surrounding software. A severe impact such as RCE is not guaranteed.
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
The impact depends on the action performed by the vulnerable code.
This could be anything from information disclosure (through the web requests) to remote code execution (in the event the request response is used to install a package or influence the application's flow).

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has a detailed technical explanation published, that can aid in exploit development
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: A technical write-up exists.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Exploitation only requires an attacker to perform a man-in-the-middle attack (which is extensively documented).

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The vulnerability is exploitable by local network attackers

data.summary: HTTP::Tiny before 0.083, a Perl core module since 5.13.9 and available standalone on CPAN, has an insecure default TLS configuration where users must opt in to verify certificates.

more_details.description: HTTP::Tiny before 0.083, a Perl core module since 5.13.9 and available standalone on CPAN, has an insecure default TLS configuration where users must opt in to verify certificates.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Missing TLS check in HTTP::Tiny allows network attackers to perform man-in-the-middle attacks when performing SSL requests.
high_profile_info.Resolution:
##### Development mitigations

Enable the `verify_SSL` flag when initializing HTTP::Tiny -

```perl
$http = HTTP::Tiny->new(verify_SSL=>1);
```

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The impact of exploiting the issue depends on the context of surrounding software. A severe impact such as RCE is not guaranteed.
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
The impact depends on the action performed by the vulnerable code.
This could be anything from information disclosure (through the web requests) to remote code execution (in the event the request response is used to install a package or influence the application's flow).

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has a detailed technical explanation published, that can aid in exploit development
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: A technical write-up exists.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Exploitation only requires an attacker to perform a man-in-the-middle attack (which is extensively documented).

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The vulnerability is exploitable by local network attackers

data.summary: Divide By Zero in vim/vim from 9.0.1367-1 to 9.0.1367-3

more_details.description: Divide By Zero in vim/vim from 9.0.1367-1 to 9.0.1367-3

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: (Non-Issue) Divide by zero in vim leads to denial of service and potentially code execution when running crafted vim commands.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Vim](https://www.vim.org/) is a free, open-source, screen-based text editor program for Unix.
Vim has an `Ex mode` that allows entering Ex commands and is designed for Batch processing.

The Ex, or colon, commands are based on the line editor named ex. In general, they operate on the document as a whole, or large portions of it (although there are commands to perform essentially every editing task).

It was discovered that when sourcing a file using Vim `Ex mode`, a divide-by-zero error may occur, which leads to a denial of service.

`vim` can be run with one or more flags. These flags include, but are not limited to:

* `-e`: With the `-e` flag, the user enters Ex mode. The Ex mode is similar to the command line mode as it also allows you to enter Ex commands.
* `-s`: With the `-s` flag, the user can silence the ex mode, to support batch commands.
* `-S`: With the `-S` flag, the user sources the file after loading it.

The issue requires the victim to run an attacker's specially crafted file in `Ex mode` and source it as well.
An example of a vulnerable command line:
`vim -e -s -S {malicious_file}`

Opening files with vim in this specific mode is highly unlikely.

This vulnerability has no security impact at all since if an attacker can run arbitrary vim commands, then the attacker can also execute arbitrary shell commands using the exclamation mark, and does not need this vulnerability to achieve code execution. For example running the vim command `!ls` will execute the shell command `ls`.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: An exploit has been published along with the original report.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: This vulnerability has no security impact since if an attacker can run arbitrary vim commands, then the attacker can also execute arbitrary shell commands using the exclamation mark, and does not need this vulnerability to achieve code execution.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The CVSS does not reflect the contextual prerequisites required to exploit the vulnerability.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploiting the issue requires the user to interact with the vulnerable software
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The victim must open the attacker's crafted text file in Vim.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: To exploit this issue Vim must be run in `Ex mode` and also source the malicious text file.

data.summary: Parsing invalid messages can panic. Parsing a text-format message which contains a potential number consisting of a minus sign, one or more characters of whitespace, and no further input will cause a panic.

more_details.description: Parsing invalid messages can panic. Parsing a text-format message which contains a potential number consisting of a minus sign, one or more characters of whitespace, and no further input will cause a panic.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: An improper input parsing in Golang's protobuf package may lead to denial of service when a crafted text buffer is parsed.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
Golang [protobuf](https://github.com/golang/protobuf) is a module that contains Go bindings and simplified API for protocol buffers.

The library implementation has a bug in the `parseNumber()` function in the `internal/encoding/text/decode_number.go` module, which does not parse correctly incomplete numbers (e.g. "s_int32: - " - contains  `-`, whitespace and no further input). Parsing incomplete numbers with no proper error handling can lead to denial of service. 

Although no public exploit is currently known for this vulnerability, attackers can find a remote input that propagates to one of the vulnerable functions and exploit this vulnerability. Attackers can simply exploit this vulnerability by sending a crafted proto message containing an incomplete negative number to cause a denial of service.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The CVSS does not reflect the contextual prerequisites required to exploit the vulnerability.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The attacker must find and control a remote input that propagates to the vulnerable function `parseNumber`. Also, protobuf text buffers must be parsed in order to trigger this issue.

data.summary: Integer overflow vulnerability in pcre2test before 10.41 allows attackers to cause a denial of service or other unspecified impacts via negative input.

more_details.description: Integer overflow vulnerability in pcre2test before 10.41 allows attackers to cause a denial of service or other unspecified impacts via negative input.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: An infinite loop in pcre2 leads to a denial of service when running pcre2test with attacker-controlled regular expressions.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
The `pcre2test` CLI tool is primarily intended for developers and individuals who are familiar with regular expressions and want a convenient way to test and debug them.
It is extremely unlikely that a regular expression pattern will be supplied from external input in a production environment.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
The GitHub Issue contains a PoC pattern that causes an infinite loop -
`./bin/pcre2test poc.zip`

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The CVSS does not reflect the contextual prerequisites required to exploit the vulnerability.

ExtendedReferences.Title: Proof of Concept in First Comment

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
The GitHub Issue contains a PoC pattern that causes an infinite loop -
`./bin/pcre2test poc.zip`

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The CVSS does not reflect the contextual prerequisites required to exploit the vulnerability.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Buffer overread in binutils leads to denial of service when reading debug information from a crafted ELF.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
The GNU [Binutils](https://www.gnu.org/software/binutils/) are a collection of binary tools. The main ones are: ld - the GNU linker, as - the GNU assembler and gold - a new, faster, ELF only linker. Most of these programs use BFD, the Binary File Descriptor library, to do low-level manipulation.
It was discovered that the BFD library can cause an out-of-bounds read when reading crafted debug info (DWARF info) from an ELF executable
For example - this can cause the `readelf` utility to crash when reading a crafted executable -
`readelf -w ./poc2`

Note that this issue cannot cause an out-of-bounds write (only an out-of-bounds read) and therefore cannot lead to code execution in any case.
In addition, the out-of-bounds read is a 1-byte read, making it unlikely to cause a crash or a meaningful data leak.
This leads to a very low severity since crashing a forked client process (ex. `readelf` or any other executable from binutils) has a negligible security impact.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: A public PoC demonstrates DoS when running `readelf` on a crafted ELF

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Crashing a forked client process (ex. objdump or any other executable from binutils) has a negligible security impact. In addition, a 1-byte overread is unlikely to cause a real-world crash or meaningful data leak.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: NVD wrongly classifies this issue as a buffer overflow, when in fact this issue is an out-of-bounds read and therefore cannot lead to code execution in any case.
