high_profile_info.ShortDescription: (Non-Issue) Buffer overflow in vim leads to denial of service and potentially code execution when running crafted vim commands.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Vim](https://www.vim.org/) is a free, open-source, screen-based text editor program for Unix.
Vim has an `Ex mode` that allows entering Ex commands and is designed for Batch processing.

The Ex, or colon, commands are based on the line editor named ex. In general, they operate on the document as a whole, or large portions of it (although there are commands to perform essentially every editing task).

It was discovered that when sourcing a file using Vim `Ex mode`, a heap overflow may occur, which leads to a denial of service.

`vim` can be run with one or more flags. These flags include, but are not limited to:

* `-e`: With the `-e` flag, the user enters Ex mode. The Ex mode is similar to the command line mode as it also allows you to enter Ex commands.
* `-s`: With the `-s` flag, the user can silence the ex mode, to support batch commands.
* `-S`: With the `-S` flag, the user sources the file after loading it.

The issue requires the victim to run an attacker's specially crafted file in `Ex mode` and source it as well.
An example of a vulnerable command line:
`vim -e -s -S {malicious_file}`

Opening files with vim in this specific mode is highly unlikely.

This vulnerability has no security impact at all since if an attacker can run arbitrary vim commands, then the attacker can also execute arbitrary shell commands using the exclamation mark, and does not need this vulnerability to achieve code execution. For example running the vim command `!ls` will execute the shell command `ls`.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: To exploit this issue Vim must be run in `Ex mode` and also source the malicious text file.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploiting the issue requires the user to interact with the vulnerable software
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The victim must open the attacker's crafted text file in Vim.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: An exploit has been published along with the original report.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The CVSS does not reflect the contextual prerequisites required to exploit the vulnerability.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: This vulnerability has no security impact since if an attacker can run arbitrary vim commands, then the attacker can also execute arbitrary shell commands using the exclamation mark, and does not need this vulnerability to achieve code execution.

data.summary: In Shadow 4.13, it is possible to inject control characters into fields provided to the SUID program chfn (change finger). Although it is not possible to exploit this directly (e.g., adding a new user fails because \n is in the block list), it is possible to misrepresent the /etc/passwd file when viewed. Use of \r manipulations and Unicode characters to work around blocking of the : character make it possible to give the impression that a new user has been added. In other words, an adversary may be able to convince a system administrator to take the system offline (an indirect, social-engineered denial of service) by demonstrating that "cat /etc/passwd" shows a rogue user account.

data.summary: The CIL compiler in SELinux 3.2 has a heap-based buffer over-read in ebitmap_match_any (called indirectly from cil_check_neverallow). This occurs because there is sometimes a lack of checks for invalid statements in an optional block.

data.summary: Python lib/smtplib.py SMTP.putcmd() Function CRLF Sequence Handling SMTP Command Injection Weakness

more_details.description: Python contains a flaw in the SMTP.putcmd() function in lib/smtplib.py that is triggered as Carriage-return New-line (CRLF) sequences are not properly sanitized. This may allow a context-dependent attacker to inject arbitrary SMTP commands.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: (Non-Issue) Buffer overread in vim leads to denial of service and potentially code execution when running crafted vim commands.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Vim](https://www.vim.org/) is a highly configurable text editor built to make creating and changing any kind of text very efficient.

It was discovered that running s specific string of vim commands (including `se`, `norm` and `sil`) will lead to a buffer overread, which crashes the application.
However, this vulnerability has no security impact at all since -

1. If an attacker can run arbitrary vim commands, then the attacker can also execute arbitrary shell commands using the exclamation mark, and does not need this vulnerability to achieve code execution. For example running the vim command `!ls` will execute the shell command `ls`.

2. A buffer overread can only lead to denial of service. Crashing a forked client process such as vim does not have any security impact.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: This vulnerability has no security impact since if an attacker can run arbitrary vim commands, then the attacker can also execute arbitrary shell commands using the exclamation mark, and does not need this vulnerability to achieve code execution

high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Vim](https://www.vim.org/) is a highly configurable text editor built to make creating and changing any kind of text very efficient.

It was discovered that running s specific string of vim commands (including `se`, `norm` and `sil`) will lead to a buffer overread, which crashes the application.
However, this vulnerability has no security impact at all since -

1. If an attacker can run arbitrary vim commands, then the attacker can also execute arbitrary shell commands using the exclamation mark, and does not need this vulnerability to achieve code execution. For example running the vim command `!ls` will execute the shell command `ls`.

2. A buffer overread can only lead to denial of service. Crashing a forked client process such as vim does not have any security impact.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: This vulnerability has no security impact since if an attacker can run arbitrary vim commands, then the attacker can also execute arbitrary shell commands using the exclamation mark, and does not need this vulnerability to achieve code execution

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: (Non-Issue) Buffer overflow in vim leads to denial of service and potentially code execution when running crafted vim commands.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Vim](https://www.vim.org/) is a free, open-source, screen-based text editor program for Unix.
Vim has an `Ex mode` that allows entering Ex commands and is designed for Batch processing.

The Ex, or colon, commands are based on the line editor named ex. In general, they operate on the document as a whole, or large portions of it (although there are commands to perform essentially every editing task).

It was discovered that when sourcing a file using Vim `Ex mode`, a heap overflow may occur, which leads to a denial of service.

`vim` can be run with one or more flags. These flags include, but are not limited to:

* `-e`: With the `-e` flag, the user enters Ex mode. The Ex mode is similar to the command line mode as it also allows you to enter Ex commands.
* `-s`: With the `-s` flag, the user can silence the ex mode, to support batch commands.
* `-S`: With the `-S` flag, the user sources the file after loading it.

The issue requires the victim to run an attacker's specially crafted file in `Ex mode` and source it as well.
An example of a vulnerable command line:
`vim -e -s -S {malicious_file}`

Opening files with vim in this specific mode is highly unlikely.

This vulnerability has no security impact at all since if an attacker can run arbitrary vim commands, then the attacker can also execute arbitrary shell commands using the exclamation mark, and does not need this vulnerability to achieve code execution. For example running the vim command `!ls` will execute the shell command `ls`.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: An exploit has been published along with the original report.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: This vulnerability has no security impact since if an attacker can run arbitrary vim commands, then the attacker can also execute arbitrary shell commands using the exclamation mark, and does not need this vulnerability to achieve code execution.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: To exploit this issue Vim must be run in `Ex mode` and also source the malicious text file.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploiting the issue requires the user to interact with the vulnerable software
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The victim must open the attacker's crafted text file in Vim.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The CVSS does not reflect the contextual prerequisites required to exploit the vulnerability.

data.summary: A vulnerability exists in curl <7.87.0 HSTS check that could be bypassed to trick it to keep using HTTP. Using its HSTS support, curl can be instructed to use HTTPS instead of using an insecure clear-text HTTP step even when HTTP is provided in the URL. However, the HSTS mechanism could be bypassed if the host name in the given URL first uses IDN characters that get replaced to ASCII counterparts as part of the IDN conversion. Like using the character UTF-8 U+3002 (IDEOGRAPHIC FULL STOP) instead of the common ASCII full stop (U+002E) `.`. Then in a subsequent request, it does not detect the HSTS state and makes a clear text transfer. Because it would store the info IDN encoded but look for it IDN decoded.

more_details.description: A vulnerability exists in curl <7.87.0 HSTS check that could be bypassed to trick it to keep using HTTP. Using its HSTS support, curl can be instructed to use HTTPS instead of using an insecure clear-text HTTP step even when HTTP is provided in the URL. However, the HSTS mechanism could be bypassed if the host name in the given URL first uses IDN characters that get replaced to ASCII counterparts as part of the IDN conversion. Like using the character UTF-8 U+3002 (IDEOGRAPHIC FULL STOP) instead of the common ASCII full stop (U+002E) `.`. Then in a subsequent request, it does not detect the HSTS state and makes a clear text transfer. Because it would store the info IDN encoded but look for it IDN decoded.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: A design problem in curl may lead to HSTS bypass when using IDN characters.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[curl](https://curl.se) is a command line tool and a library for transferring data, supporting various network protocols. 

[HTTP Strict Transport Security](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Security/HTTP_strict_transport_security) (HSTS) is a simple and widely supported standard to protect visitors by ensuring that their browsers always connect to a website over HTTPS. HSTS exists to remove the need for the common, insecure practice of redirecting users from `http://` to `https://` URLs.

[Internationalized Domain Names](https://help.dreamhost.com/hc/en-us/articles/215864977-Internationalized-domain-names-IDNs-) (IDNs) are domain names that contain characters other than unaccented Roman letters (A-Z), digits (0-9), and the hyphen. For instance, `日本語.idn.icann.org` contains Japanese characters.

`curl` features an in-memory cache for `HSTS` hosts, so subsequent `HTTP-only` requests to a hostname present in the cache will get internally "redirected" to the `HTTPS` version.

It was discovered that the `HSTS` mechanism could be bypassed if the hostname in the given URL first uses `IDN` characters that get replaced with ASCII counterparts as part of the `IDN` conversion. Like using the UTF-8 character `U+3002` (IDEOGRAPHIC FULL STOP) instead of the common `ASCII` full stop (U+002E) `.`. Then in a subsequent request, it does not detect the `HSTS` state and makes a clear text transfer. 

The cause of this issue is that `curl` would store the `HSTS` info `IDN`-encoded but look for it `IDN`-decoded, resulting from a partial fix for a similar issue: CVE-2022-43551.

The vulnerability is exploitable only when `curl` is executed with the non-default `--hsts` option.

Example command-line usage that can trigger this issue -
```
curl -v --hsts hsts.txt https://accounts.google%E3%80%82com
curl -v --hsts hsts.txt http://accounts.google%E3%80%82com
```

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
1. The vulnerability is exploitable only when `curl` is executed with the `--hsts` option that caches the HSTS hosts and then subsequent HTTP requests with the `--hsts` option that checks if an HTTPS redirection should occur.
2. The exploitation of this vulnerability may only be useful in environments exposed to Man in the Middle attacks. This would give the attacker the ability to perform Man in the Middle on non-encrypted clear text communication, which is easier compared to encrypted communication when HTTPS is used.
3. The vulnerable application or server should execute`curl` that would access Internationalized Domain Names (IDNs), which is not common. Alternatively, the attacker should be able to control the requested URL that `curl` access and set it to an IDN address.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has a detailed technical explanation published, that can aid in exploit development
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: HackerOne report has a detailed technical writeup that leads to HSTS bypass.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The CVSS does not reflect the contextual prerequisites required to exploit the vulnerability.

ExtendedReferences.Title: HackerOne Report with a technical writeup

data.summary:
This flaw allows an attacker to insert cookies at will into a running program
using libcurl, if the specific series of conditions are met.

libcurl performs transfers. In its API, an application creates "easy handles"
that are the individual handles for single transfers.

libcurl provides a function call that duplicates en easy handle called
[curl_easy_duphandle](https://curl.se/libcurl/c/curl_easy_duphandle.html).

If a transfer has cookies enabled when the handle is duplicated, the
cookie-enable state is also cloned - but without cloning the actual
cookies. If the source handle did not read any cookies from a specific file on
disk, the cloned version of the handle would instead store the file name as
`none` (using the four ASCII letters, no quotes).

Subsequent use of the cloned handle that does not explicitly set a source to
load cookies from would then inadvertently load cookies from a file named
`none` - if such a file exists and is readable in the current directory of the
program using libcurl. And if using the correct file format of course.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Unspecified low-severity vulnerability in libcurl (fix pending)
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Curl](https://curl.se/) is a command-line tool for transferring data from or to a server, using various protocols like HTTP, FTP, SMTP, and more.
Daniel Stenberg, one of Curl’s core maintainers announced that a forthcoming release of Curl, version 8.4.0, is scheduled to be available one week from that date, on October 11th, 2023 at approximately 06:00 UTC. This release will fix two security vulnerabilities in curl.
One of these vulnerabilities is rated as having low severity - CVE-2023-38546.
As of the current moment, no specific details (such as affected versions) have been released.

While not much is known about CVE-2023-38545 the following has been verified by official sources -
1. CVE-2023-38545 is “the worst security problem found in Curl in a long time”. For reference, the last vulnerability that was given a “High” severity by the Curl project is CVE-2021-22901 that was reported in May 2011.
2. The vulnerability does not affect all users of Curl, the maintainers specifically mentioned “there is still going to be a large chunk of users who will not be affected by these problems” - probably due to attack preconditions of this vulnerability.
3. The vulnerability is rated “High” although the Curl project does theoretically support designating vulnerabilities as “Critical” (this never happened so far). This may be related to the previous point - not all users are affected.
4. There is no API nor ABI change in the coming curl release.

This advisory will be updated on October 11th 2023 as details emerge

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has multiple mentions in general media
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The vulnerability received extensive media coverage due to the popularity of curl and its connection to CVE-2023-38545 (which has high severity)

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Unspecified low-severity vulnerability in libcurl (fix pending)
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Curl](https://curl.se/) is a command-line tool for transferring data from or to a server, using various protocols like HTTP, FTP, SMTP, and more.
Daniel Stenberg, one of Curl’s core maintainers announced that a forthcoming release of Curl, version 8.4.0, is scheduled to be available one week from that date, on October 11th, 2023 at approximately 06:00 UTC. This release will fix two security vulnerabilities in curl.
One of these vulnerabilities is rated as having low severity - CVE-2023-38546.
As of the current moment, no specific details (such as affected versions) have been released.

While not much is known about CVE-2023-38545 the following has been verified by official sources -
1. CVE-2023-38545 is “the worst security problem found in Curl in a long time”. For reference, the last vulnerability that was given a “High” severity by the Curl project is CVE-2021-22901 that was reported in May 2011.
2. The vulnerability does not affect all users of Curl, the maintainers specifically mentioned “there is still going to be a large chunk of users who will not be affected by these problems” - probably due to attack preconditions of this vulnerability.
3. The vulnerability is rated “High” although the Curl project does theoretically support designating vulnerabilities as “Critical” (this never happened so far). This may be related to the previous point - not all users are affected.
4. There is no API nor ABI change in the coming curl release.

This advisory will be updated on October 11th 2023 as details emerge

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has multiple mentions in general media
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The vulnerability received extensive media coverage due to the popularity of curl and its connection to CVE-2023-38545 (which has high severity)

data.summary: A vulnerability exists in curl <7.87.0 HSTS check that could be bypassed to trick it to keep using HTTP. Using its HSTS support, curl can be instructed to use HTTPS instead of using an insecure clear-text HTTP step even when HTTP is provided in the URL. However, the HSTS mechanism could be bypassed if the host name in the given URL first uses IDN characters that get replaced to ASCII counterparts as part of the IDN conversion. Like using the character UTF-8 U+3002 (IDEOGRAPHIC FULL STOP) instead of the common ASCII full stop (U+002E) `.`. Then in a subsequent request, it does not detect the HSTS state and makes a clear text transfer. Because it would store the info IDN encoded but look for it IDN decoded.

Using its HSTS support, curl can be instructed to use HTTPS instead of using an insecure clear-text HTTP step even when HTTP is provided in the URL. However, the HSTS mechanism could be bypassed if the host name in the given URL first uses IDN characters that get replaced to ASCII counterparts as part of the IDN conversion. Like using the character UTF-8 U+3002 (IDEOGRAPHIC FULL STOP) instead of the common ASCII full stop (U+002E) `.`. Then in a subsequent request, it does not detect the HSTS state and makes a clear text transfer. Because it would store the info IDN encoded but look for it IDN decoded.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: A design problem in curl may lead to HSTS bypass when using IDN characters.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[curl](https://curl.se) is a command line tool and a library for transferring data, supporting various network protocols. 

[HTTP Strict Transport Security](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Security/HTTP_strict_transport_security) (HSTS) is a simple and widely supported standard to protect visitors by ensuring that their browsers always connect to a website over HTTPS. HSTS exists to remove the need for the common, insecure practice of redirecting users from `http://` to `https://` URLs.

[Internationalized Domain Names](https://help.dreamhost.com/hc/en-us/articles/215864977-Internationalized-domain-names-IDNs-) (IDNs) are domain names that contain characters other than unaccented Roman letters (A-Z), digits (0-9), and the hyphen. For instance, `日本語.idn.icann.org` contains Japanese characters.

`curl` features an in-memory cache for `HSTS` hosts, so subsequent `HTTP-only` requests to a hostname present in the cache will get internally "redirected" to the `HTTPS` version.

It was discovered that the `HSTS` mechanism could be bypassed if the hostname in the given URL first uses `IDN` characters that get replaced with ASCII counterparts as part of the `IDN` conversion. Like using the UTF-8 character `U+3002` (IDEOGRAPHIC FULL STOP) instead of the common `ASCII` full stop (U+002E) `.`. Then in a subsequent request, it does not detect the `HSTS` state and makes a clear text transfer. 

The cause of this issue is that `curl` would store the `HSTS` info `IDN`-encoded but look for it `IDN`-decoded, resulting from a partial fix for a similar issue: CVE-2022-43551.

The vulnerability is exploitable only when `curl` is executed with the non-default `--hsts` option.

Example command-line usage that can trigger this issue -
```
curl -v --hsts hsts.txt https://accounts.google%E3%80%82com
curl -v --hsts hsts.txt http://accounts.google%E3%80%82com
```

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
1. The vulnerability is exploitable only when `curl` is executed with the `--hsts` option that caches the HSTS hosts and then subsequent HTTP requests with the `--hsts` option that checks if an HTTPS redirection should occur.
2. The exploitation of this vulnerability may only be useful in environments exposed to Man in the Middle attacks. This would give the attacker the ability to perform Man in the Middle on non-encrypted clear text communication, which is easier compared to encrypted communication when HTTPS is used.
3. The vulnerable application or server should execute`curl` that would access Internationalized Domain Names (IDNs), which is not common. Alternatively, the attacker should be able to control the requested URL that `curl` access and set it to an IDN address.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has a detailed technical explanation published, that can aid in exploit development
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: HackerOne report has a detailed technical writeup that leads to HSTS bypass.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The CVSS does not reflect the contextual prerequisites required to exploit the vulnerability.

ExtendedReferences.Title: HackerOne Report with a technical writeup

data.summary: In curl before 7.86.0, the HSTS check could be bypassed to trick it into staying with HTTP. Using its HSTS support, curl can be instructed to use HTTPS directly (instead of using an insecure cleartext HTTP step) even when HTTP is provided in the URL. This mechanism could be bypassed if the host name in the given URL uses IDN characters that get replaced with ASCII counterparts as part of the IDN conversion, e.g., using the character UTF-8 U+3002 (IDEOGRAPHIC FULL STOP) instead of the common ASCII full stop of U+002E (.). The earliest affected version is 7.77.0 2021-05-26.

data.summary:
This flaw makes curl overflow a heap based buffer in the SOCKS5 proxy
handshake.

When curl is asked to pass along the host name to the SOCKS5 proxy to allow
that to resolve the address instead of it getting done by curl itself, the
maximum length that host name can be is 255 bytes.

If the host name is detected to be longer, curl switches to local name
resolving and instead passes on the resolved address only. Due to this bug,
the local variable that means "let the host resolve the name" could get the
wrong value during a slow SOCKS5 handshake, and contrary to the intention,
copy the too long host name to the target buffer instead of copying just the
resolved address there.

The target buffer being a heap based buffer, and the host name coming from the
URL that curl has been told to operate with.

This flaw makes curl overflow a heap based buffer in the SOCKS5 proxy

If the host name is detected to be longer, curl switches to local name
resolving and instead passes on the resolved address only. Due to this bug,
the local variable that means "let the host resolve the name" could get the
wrong value during a slow SOCKS5 handshake, and contrary to the intention,
copy the too long host name to the target buffer instead of copying just the
resolved address there.

The target buffer being a heap based buffer, and the host name coming from the
URL that curl has been told to operate with.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Heap overflow in curl and libcurl leads to remote code execution when connecting to malicious HTTP servers over SOCKS5 proxies with remote hostname resolving.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Curl](https://curl.se/) is a command-line tool for transferring data from or to a server, using various protocols like HTTP, FTP, SMTP, and more.
It was discovered that when connecting to a malicious HTTP server over a SOCKS5 proxy with remote hostname resolving (scheme `socks5h://`) a heap overflow can be triggered due to a long (attacker-controlled) hostname being copied to a small local heap-based buffer.

The vulnerability affects both the `curl` CLI tool and the `libcurl` library, but not under default conditions.

The `libcurl` library is only vulnerable if used in any of the following ways - 

* `CURLOPT_PROXYTYPE` set to type `CURLPROXY_SOCKS5_HOSTNAME`, ex. -
`curl_easy_setopt(handle, CURLOPT_PROXYTYPE, CURLPROXY_SOCKS5_HOSTNAME)`

* `CURLOPT_PROXY` or `CURLOPT_PRE_PROXY` set to use the scheme `socks5h://`, ex. -
`curl_easy_setopt(handle, CURLOPT_PROXY, "socks5h://...")`

* One of the proxy environment variables is set to use the `socks5h://` scheme. For example the environment variables `http_proxy`, `HTTPS_PROXY` or `ALL_PROXY`.


The `curl` CLI tool is only vulnerable if any of the following conditions are true -

* Executed with `--socks5-hostname` flag
* Executed with `--proxy` (`-x`) or `--preproxy` set to use the scheme `socks5h://`
* Executed with relevant environment variables as described above

Example of a vulnerable `curl` invocation -
`curl -x socks5h://myproxy.com malicioushost.com`

In addition to the following conditions, the `curl` CLI tool in version 8.x  is only vulnerable if the flag `--limit-rate` is set with a number smaller than 65541.
(To clarify, this additional condition is not required for exploitation of `libcurl` or `curl` CLI version 7.x)

[An exploit](https://gist.github.com/xen0bit/0dccb11605abbeb6021963e2b1a811d3) for this vulnerability is publicly available, which demonstrates denial of service via [read-access to an attacker-controlled pointer](https://twitter.com/_JohnHammond/status/1711976730775470564/photo/1). While remote code execution exploit has not been published or discussed at this time, heap overflows can often be exploited for remote code execution.
high_profile_info.Resolution:
##### Deployment mitigations

Force curl to use local hostname resolving instead of remote hostname resolving when connecting to a SOCKS5 proxy

For example, replace `socks5h` -
`curl -x socks5h://someproxy.com`

With `socks5` -
`curl -x socks5://someproxy.com`

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has multiple mentions in general media
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The vulnerability received extensive media coverage due to the popularity of curl and the scarcity of high-severity vulnerabilities in curl.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: [An exploit](https://gist.github.com/xen0bit/0dccb11605abbeb6021963e2b1a811d3) for this vulnerability is publicly available, which demonstrates denial of service via [read-access to an attacker-controlled pointer](https://twitter.com/_JohnHammond/status/1711976730775470564/photo/1). While remote code execution exploit has not been published or discussed at this time, heap overflows can often be exploited for remote code execution.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Curl or libcurl must be configured to connect to an attacker-controlled HTTP server over a SOCKS5 proxy, with remote hostname resolving specifically enabled in the curl client.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Possible remote code execution

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
Use of curl with SOCKS5 proxies with remote hostname resolving (`socks5h://` scheme) is rare.
In addition, the curl CLI tool in version 8.x is only vulnerable if the flag `--limit-rate` is explicitly set with a number smaller than 65541.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: [An exploit](https://gist.github.com/xen0bit/0dccb11605abbeb6021963e2b1a811d3) for this vulnerability is publicly available, which demonstrates denial of service via [read-access to an attacker-controlled pointer](https://twitter.com/_JohnHammond/status/1711976730775470564/photo/1). While remote code execution exploit has not been published or discussed at this time, heap overflows can often be exploited for remote code execution.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Curl or libcurl must be configured to connect to an attacker-controlled HTTP server over a SOCKS5 proxy, with remote hostname resolving specifically enabled in the curl client.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue can be exploited by attackers over the network
The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
Use of curl with SOCKS5 proxies with remote hostname resolving (`socks5h://` scheme) is rare.
In addition, the curl CLI tool in version 8.x is only vulnerable if the flag `--limit-rate` is explicitly set with a number smaller than 65541.

data.summary:
This flaw makes curl overflow a heap based buffer in the SOCKS5 proxy
handshake.

When curl is asked to pass along the host name to the SOCKS5 proxy to allow
that to resolve the address instead of it getting done by curl itself, the
maximum length that host name can be is 255 bytes.

If the host name is detected to be longer, curl switches to local name
resolving and instead passes on the resolved address only. Due to this bug,
the local variable that means "let the host resolve the name" could get the
wrong value during a slow SOCKS5 handshake, and contrary to the intention,
copy the too long host name to the target buffer instead of copying just the
resolved address there.

The target buffer being a heap based buffer, and the host name coming from the
URL that curl has been told to operate with.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Heap overflow in curl and libcurl leads to remote code execution when connecting to malicious HTTP servers over SOCKS5 proxies with remote hostname resolving.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Curl](https://curl.se/) is a command-line tool for transferring data from or to a server, using various protocols like HTTP, FTP, SMTP, and more.
It was discovered that when connecting to a malicious HTTP server over a SOCKS5 proxy with remote hostname resolving (scheme `socks5h://`) a heap overflow can be triggered due to a long (attacker-controlled) hostname being copied to a small local heap-based buffer.

The vulnerability affects both the `curl` CLI tool and the `libcurl` library, but not under default conditions.

The `libcurl` library is only vulnerable if used in any of the following ways - 

* `CURLOPT_PROXYTYPE` set to type `CURLPROXY_SOCKS5_HOSTNAME`, ex. -
`curl_easy_setopt(handle, CURLOPT_PROXYTYPE, CURLPROXY_SOCKS5_HOSTNAME)`

* `CURLOPT_PROXY` or `CURLOPT_PRE_PROXY` set to use the scheme `socks5h://`, ex. -
`curl_easy_setopt(handle, CURLOPT_PROXY, "socks5h://...")`

* One of the proxy environment variables is set to use the `socks5h://` scheme. For example the environment variables `http_proxy`, `HTTPS_PROXY` or `ALL_PROXY`.


The `curl` CLI tool is only vulnerable if any of the following conditions are true -

* Executed with `--socks5-hostname` flag
* Executed with `--proxy` (`-x`) or `--preproxy` set to use the scheme `socks5h://`
* Executed with relevant environment variables as described above

Example of a vulnerable `curl` invocation -
`curl -x socks5h://myproxy.com malicioushost.com`

In addition to the following conditions, the `curl` CLI tool in version 8.x  is only vulnerable if the flag `--limit-rate` is set with a number smaller than 65541.
(To clarify, this additional condition is not required for exploitation of `libcurl` or `curl` CLI version 7.x)

[An exploit](https://gist.github.com/xen0bit/0dccb11605abbeb6021963e2b1a811d3) for this vulnerability is publicly available, which demonstrates denial of service via [read-access to an attacker-controlled pointer](https://twitter.com/_JohnHammond/status/1711976730775470564/photo/1). While remote code execution exploit has not been published or discussed at this time, heap overflows can often be exploited for remote code execution.
high_profile_info.Resolution:
##### Deployment mitigations

Force curl to use local hostname resolving instead of remote hostname resolving when connecting to a SOCKS5 proxy

For example, replace `socks5h` -
`curl -x socks5h://someproxy.com`

With `socks5` -
`curl -x socks5://someproxy.com`
